<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">The Beatles</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">English rock band (1960–1970)</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">This article is about the band. For their eponymous album, see <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles_(album)" title="The Beatles (album)"><i>The Beatles</i> (album)</a>. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Beatles_(disambiguation)" title="Beatles (disambiguation)">Beatles (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"Beatle" and "Fab Four" redirect here. For the insect, see <a href="/wiki/Beetle" title="Beetle">Beetle</a>. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Fab_Four_(disambiguation)" title="Fab Four (disambiguation)">Fab Four (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1066479718">.mw-parser-output .infobox-subbox{padding:0;border:none;margin:-3px;width:auto;min-width:100%;font-size:100%;clear:none;float:none;background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .infobox-3cols-child{margin:auto}.mw-parser-output .infobox .navbar{font-size:100%}body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-header,body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-subheader,body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-above,body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-title,body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-image,body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-full-data,body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .infobox-below{text-align:center}</style><table class="infobox vcard plainlist"><tbody><tr><th class="infobox-above" colspan="2" style="background-color: #b0c4de; font-size: 125%;"><div class="">The Beatles</div></th></tr><tr><td class="infobox-image" colspan="2"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Fabs.JPG" title="A square quartered into four head shots of young men with moptop haircuts. All four wear white shirts and dark coats."><img alt="A square quartered into four head shots of young men with moptop haircuts. All four wear white shirts and dark coats." data-file-height="1110" data-file-width="1110" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/The_Fabs.JPG/220px-The_Fabs.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/The_Fabs.JPG/330px-The_Fabs.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/The_Fabs.JPG/440px-The_Fabs.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a><div class="infobox-caption">The Beatles in 1964; clockwise from top left: John Lennon, Paul McCartney, Ringo Starr and George Harrison</div></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-header" colspan="2" style="background-color: #b0c4de">Background information</th></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Origin</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Liverpool" title="Liverpool">Liverpool</a>, England</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Genres</th><td class="infobox-data"><div class="hlist hlist-separated"><ul><li><a href="/wiki/Rock_music" title="Rock music">Rock</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Pop_music" title="Pop music">pop</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Beat_music" title="Beat music">beat</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Psychedelic_music" title="Psychedelic music">psychedelia</a></li></ul></div></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><span class="nowrap">Years active</span></th><td class="infobox-data">1960–1970</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Labels</th><td class="infobox-data"><div class="hlist hlist-separated"><ul><li><a href="/wiki/Parlophone" title="Parlophone">Parlophone</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Apple_Records" title="Apple Records">Apple</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Capitol_Records" title="Capitol Records">Capitol</a></li></ul></div></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Spinoffs</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Plastic_Ono_Band" title="Plastic Ono Band">Plastic Ono Band</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Spinoff of</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/The_Quarrymen" title="The Quarrymen">The Quarrymen</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-header" colspan="2" style="background-color: #b0c4de"></th></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><span class="nowrap">Past members</span></th><td class="infobox-data">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/John_Lennon" title="John Lennon">John Lennon</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Paul_McCartney" title="Paul McCartney">Paul McCartney</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/George_Harrison" title="George Harrison">George Harrison</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ringo_Starr" title="Ringo Starr">Ringo Starr</a></li>
<li>(see <a href="#Personnel">Personnel section</a> for others)</li></ul>
</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-header" colspan="2" style="background-color: #b0c4de"></th></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Website</th><td class="infobox-data"><span class="url"><a class="external text" href="http://thebeatles.com" rel="nofollow">thebeatles<wbr/>.com</a></span></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>The Beatles</b> were an English <a href="/wiki/Rock_music" title="Rock music">rock</a> band, formed in <a href="/wiki/Liverpool" title="Liverpool">Liverpool</a> in 1960, that comprised <a href="/wiki/John_Lennon" title="John Lennon">John Lennon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paul_McCartney" title="Paul McCartney">Paul McCartney</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_Harrison" title="George Harrison">George Harrison</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ringo_Starr" title="Ringo Starr">Ringo Starr</a>. They are regarded as the <a href="/wiki/Cultural_impact_of_the_Beatles" title="Cultural impact of the Beatles">most influential band of all time</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHasted2017425_1-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHasted2017425-1">[1]</a></sup> and were integral to the development of <a href="/wiki/Counterculture_of_the_1960s" title="Counterculture of the 1960s">1960s counterculture</a> and <a href="/wiki/Popular_music" title="Popular music">popular music</a>'s recognition as an art form.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrontani2007125_2-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrontani2007125-2">[2]</a></sup> Rooted in <a href="/wiki/Skiffle" title="Skiffle">skiffle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beat_music" title="Beat music">beat</a> and 1950s <a href="/wiki/Rock_and_roll" title="Rock and roll">rock 'n' roll</a>, their sound incorporated elements of <a href="/wiki/Classical_music" title="Classical music">classical music</a> and <a href="/wiki/Traditional_pop" title="Traditional pop">traditional pop</a> in innovative ways; the band later explored music styles ranging from <a href="/wiki/Sentimental_ballad" title="Sentimental ballad">ballads</a> and <a href="/wiki/Music_of_India" title="Music of India">Indian music</a> to <a href="/wiki/Psychedelic_music" title="Psychedelic music">psychedelia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hard_rock" title="Hard rock">hard rock</a>. As <a href="/wiki/Recording_practices_of_the_Beatles" title="Recording practices of the Beatles">pioneers in recording</a>, songwriting and artistic presentation, the Beatles revolutionised many aspects of the music industry and were often publicised as leaders of the era's <a href="/wiki/Baby_boomers" title="Baby boomers">youth</a> and sociocultural movements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrontani2007157_3-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrontani2007157-3">[3]</a></sup>
</p><p>Led by primary songwriters <a href="/wiki/Lennon%E2%80%93McCartney" title="Lennon–McCartney">Lennon and McCartney</a>, the Beatles evolved from Lennon's previous group, <a href="/wiki/The_Quarrymen" title="The Quarrymen">the Quarrymen</a>, and built their reputation playing clubs in Liverpool and <a href="/wiki/Hamburg" title="Hamburg">Hamburg</a> over three years from 1960, initially with <a href="/wiki/Stuart_Sutcliffe" title="Stuart Sutcliffe">Stuart Sutcliffe</a> playing <a href="/wiki/Bass_guitar" title="Bass guitar">bass</a>. The core trio of Lennon, McCartney and Harrison, together since 1958, went through a succession of drummers, including <a href="/wiki/Pete_Best" title="Pete Best">Pete Best</a>, before asking Starr to join them in 1962. Manager <a href="/wiki/Brian_Epstein" title="Brian Epstein">Brian Epstein</a> moulded them into a professional act, and producer <a href="/wiki/George_Martin" title="George Martin">George Martin</a> guided and developed their recordings, greatly expanding their domestic success after signing to <a href="/wiki/EMI_Records" title="EMI Records">EMI Records</a> and achieving their first hit, "<a href="/wiki/Love_Me_Do" title="Love Me Do">Love Me Do</a>", in late 1962. As their popularity grew into the intense fan frenzy dubbed "<a href="/wiki/Beatlemania" title="Beatlemania">Beatlemania</a>", the band acquired the nickname "the Fab Four", with Epstein, Martin or another member of the band's entourage sometimes informally referred to as a "<a href="/wiki/Fifth_Beatle" title="Fifth Beatle">fifth Beatle</a>".
</p><p>By early 1964, the Beatles were international stars and had achieved unprecedented levels of critical and commercial success. They became a leading force in Britain's cultural resurgence, ushering in the <a href="/wiki/British_Invasion" title="British Invasion">British Invasion</a> of the United States pop market, and soon made their film debut with <i><a href="/wiki/A_Hard_Day%27s_Night_(film)" title="A Hard Day's Night (film)">A Hard Day's Night</a></i> (1964). A growing desire to refine their studio efforts, coupled with the untenable nature of their concert tours, led to the band's <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles%27_1966_US_tour" title="The Beatles' 1966 US tour">retirement from live performances</a> in 1966. At this time, they produced records of greater sophistication, including the albums <i><a href="/wiki/Rubber_Soul" title="Rubber Soul">Rubber Soul</a></i> (1965), <i><a href="/wiki/Revolver_(Beatles_album)" title="Revolver (Beatles album)">Revolver</a></i> (1966) and <i><a href="/wiki/Sgt._Pepper%27s_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band" title="Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band">Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band</a></i> (1967), and enjoyed further commercial success with <i><a href="/wiki/The_Beatles_(album)" title="The Beatles (album)">The Beatles</a></i> (also known as "the White Album", 1968) and <i><a href="/wiki/Abbey_Road" title="Abbey Road">Abbey Road</a></i> (1969). The success of these records heralded the <a href="/wiki/Album_era" title="Album era">album era</a>, as albums became the dominant form of record consumption over <a href="/wiki/Single_(music)" title="Single (music)">singles</a>; they also increased public interest in <a href="/wiki/Psychedelic_drug" title="Psychedelic drug">psychedelic drugs</a> and Eastern spirituality, and furthered advancements in <a href="/wiki/Electronic_music" title="Electronic music">electronic music</a>, album art and <a href="/wiki/Music_video" title="Music video">music videos</a>. In 1968, they founded <a href="/wiki/Apple_Corps" title="Apple Corps">Apple Corps</a>, a multi-armed multimedia corporation that continues to oversee projects related to the band's legacy. After <a href="/wiki/Break-up_of_the_Beatles" title="Break-up of the Beatles">the group's break-up</a> in 1970, all principal former members enjoyed success as solo artists and some <a href="/wiki/Collaborations_between_ex-Beatles" title="Collaborations between ex-Beatles">partial reunions</a> have occurred. Lennon <a href="/wiki/Murder_of_John_Lennon" title="Murder of John Lennon">was murdered</a> in 1980 and Harrison died of lung cancer in 2001. McCartney and Starr remain musically active.
</p><p>The Beatles are the <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_music_artists" title="List of best-selling music artists">best-selling music act of all time</a>, with estimated sales of 600 million units worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-5"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup> They hold the record for most number-one albums on the <a href="/wiki/UK_Albums_Chart" title="UK Albums Chart">UK Albums Chart</a> (15), <a href="/wiki/List_of_Billboard_Hot_100_chart_achievements_and_milestones" title="List of Billboard Hot 100 chart achievements and milestones">most number-one hits</a> on the US <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100"><i>Billboard</i> Hot 100</a> chart (20), and most singles sold in the UK (21.9 million). The band received <a href="/wiki/List_of_awards_and_nominations_received_by_the_Beatles" title="List of awards and nominations received by the Beatles">many accolades</a>, including seven <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grammy_Award" title="Grammy Award">Grammy Awards</a>, four <a href="/wiki/Brit_Awards" title="Brit Awards">Brit Awards</a>, an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Academy_Award" title="Academy Award">Academy Award</a> (for <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Score#1970s" title="Academy Award for Best Original Score">Best Original Song Score</a> for the 1970 documentary film <i><a href="/wiki/Let_It_Be_(1970_film)" title="Let It Be (1970 film)">Let It Be</a></i>) and fifteen <a href="/wiki/Ivor_Novello_Awards" title="Ivor Novello Awards">Ivor Novello Awards</a>. They were inducted into the <a href="/wiki/Rock_and_Roll_Hall_of_Fame" title="Rock and Roll Hall of Fame">Rock and Roll Hall of Fame</a> in 1988, and each principal member was inducted individually between 1994 and 2015. In 2004 and 2011, the group topped <i><a href="/wiki/Rolling_Stone" title="Rolling Stone">Rolling Stone</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s lists of <a href="/wiki/Rolling_Stone%27s_100_Greatest_Artists_of_All_Time" title="Rolling Stone's 100 Greatest Artists of All Time">the greatest artists in history</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i> magazine named them among the <a href="/wiki/Time_100:_The_Most_Important_People_of_the_Century" title="Time 100: The Most Important People of the Century">20th century's 100 most important people</a>.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1045330069">.mw-parser-output .sidebar{width:22em;float:right;clear:right;margin:0.5em 0 1em 1em;background:#f8f9fa;border:1px solid #aaa;padding:0.2em;text-align:center;line-height:1.4em;font-size:88%;border-collapse:collapse;display:table}body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .sidebar{display:table!important;float:right!important;margin:0.5em 0 1em 1em!important}.mw-parser-output .sidebar-subgroup{width:100%;margin:0;border-spacing:0}.mw-parser-output .sidebar-left{float:left;clear:left;margin:0.5em 1em 1em 0}.mw-parser-output .sidebar-none{float:none;clear:both;margin:0.5em 1em 1em 0}.mw-parser-output .sidebar-outer-title{padding:0 0.4em </tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1063604349">.mw-parser-output .navbar{display:inline;font-size:88%;font-weight:normal}.mw-parser-output .navbar-collapse{float:left;text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .navbar-boxtext{word-spacing:0}.mw-parser-output .navbar ul{display:inline-block;white-space:nowrap;line-height:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::before{margin-right:-0.125em;content:"[ "}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::after{margin-left:-0.125em;content:" ]"}.mw-parser-output .navbar li{word-spacing:-0.125em}.mw-parser-output .navbar a>span,.mw-parser-output .navbar a>abbr{text-decoration:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-mini abbr{font-variant:small-caps;border-bottom:none;text-decoration:none;cursor:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-full{font-size:114%;margin:0 7em}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-mini{font-size:114%;margin:0 4em}</style><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:The_Beatles_history" title="Template:The Beatles history"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:The_Beatles_history" title="Template talk:The Beatles history"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:The_Beatles_history&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<h3><span id="1956.E2.80.931963:_Formation"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1956–1963:_Formation"><span id="Formation"></span> 1956–1963: Formation</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Quarrymen_and_name_changes">The Quarrymen and name changes</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/The_Quarrymen" title="The Quarrymen">The Quarrymen</a></div>
<p>In November 1956, sixteen-year-old <a href="/wiki/John_Lennon" title="John Lennon">John Lennon</a> formed a <a href="/wiki/Skiffle" title="Skiffle">skiffle</a> group with several friends from <a href="/wiki/Calderstones_School" title="Calderstones School">Quarry Bank High School</a> in <a href="/wiki/Liverpool" title="Liverpool">Liverpool</a>. They briefly called themselves the Blackjacks, before changing their name to <a href="/wiki/The_Quarrymen" title="The Quarrymen">the Quarrymen</a> after discovering that another local group were already using the name.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpitz200547–52_6-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpitz200547–52-6">[6]</a></sup> Fifteen-year-old <a href="/wiki/Paul_McCartney" title="Paul McCartney">Paul McCartney</a> met Lennon on 6 July 1957, and joined as a <a href="/wiki/Rhythm_guitar" title="Rhythm guitar">rhythm guitarist</a> shortly after.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpitz200593–99_7-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpitz200593–99-7">[7]</a></sup> In February 1958, McCartney invited his friend <a href="/wiki/George_Harrison" title="George Harrison">George Harrison</a>, then fifteen, to watch the band. Harrison auditioned for Lennon, impressing him with his playing, but Lennon initially thought Harrison was too young. After a month's persistence, during a second meeting (arranged by McCartney), Harrison performed the lead guitar part of the instrumental song "<a href="/wiki/Raunchy_(instrumental)" title="Raunchy (instrumental)">Raunchy</a>" on the upper deck of a Liverpool bus,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup> and they enlisted him as <a href="/wiki/Lead_guitar" title="Lead guitar">lead guitarist</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiles199747_9-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiles199747-9">[9]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199213_10-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199213-10">[10]</a></sup>
</p><p>By January 1959, Lennon's Quarry Bank friends had left the group, and he began his studies at the <a href="/wiki/Liverpool_College_of_Art" title="Liverpool College of Art">Liverpool College of Art</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a103_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a103-11">[11]</a></sup> The three guitarists, billing themselves as Johnny and the Moondogs,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199217_12-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199217-12">[12]</a></sup> were playing <a href="/wiki/Rock_and_roll" title="Rock and roll">rock and roll</a> whenever they could find a drummer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000b742–743_13-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000b742–743-13">[13]</a></sup> Lennon's art school friend <a href="/wiki/Stuart_Sutcliffe" title="Stuart Sutcliffe">Stuart Sutcliffe</a>, who had just sold one of his paintings and was persuaded to purchase a bass guitar with the proceeds, joined in January 1960. He suggested changing the band's name to <i>Beatals</i>, as a tribute to <a href="/wiki/Buddy_Holly" title="Buddy Holly">Buddy Holly</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Crickets" title="The Crickets">the Crickets</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199218_14-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199218-14">[14]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGilliland1969show_27,_track_4_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGilliland1969show_27,_track_4-15">[15]</a></sup> They used this name until May, when they became the Silver Beetles, before undertaking a brief <a href="/wiki/The_Beat_Ballad_Show_Tour" title="The Beat Ballad Show Tour">tour of Scotland</a> as the backing group for pop singer and fellow <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Liverpudlian" title="Liverpudlian">Liverpudlian</a> <a href="/wiki/Johnny_Gentle" title="Johnny Gentle">Johnny Gentle</a>. By early July, they had refashioned themselves as the Silver Beatles, and by the middle of August simply <i>the Beatles</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199218–22_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199218–22-16">[16]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_residencies_and_UK_popularity">Early residencies and UK popularity</span></h4>
<p><a href="/wiki/Allan_Williams" title="Allan Williams">Allan Williams</a>, the Beatles' unofficial manager, arranged a residency for them <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles_in_Hamburg" title="The Beatles in Hamburg">in Hamburg</a>. They auditioned and hired drummer <a href="/wiki/Pete_Best" title="Pete Best">Pete Best</a> in mid-August 1960. The band, now a five-piece, departed Liverpool for Hamburg four days later, contracted to club owner <a href="/wiki/Bruno_Koschmider" title="Bruno Koschmider">Bruno Koschmider</a> for what would be a <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1020198016">.mw-parser-output .frac{white-space:nowrap}.mw-parser-output .frac .num,.mw-parser-output .frac .den{font-size:80%;line-height:0;vertical-align:super}.mw-parser-output .frac .den{vertical-align:sub}.mw-parser-output .sr-only{border:0;clip:rect(0,0,0,0);height:1px;margin:-1px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;position:absolute;width:1px}</style><span class="frac" role="math">3<span class="sr-only">+</span><span class="num">1</span>⁄<span class="den">2</span></span>-month residency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199221–25_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199221–25-17">[17]</a></sup> Beatles historian <a href="/wiki/Mark_Lewisohn" title="Mark Lewisohn">Mark Lewisohn</a> writes: "They pulled into Hamburg at dusk on 17 August, the time when the <a href="/wiki/Reeperbahn" title="Reeperbahn">red-light area</a> comes to life ... flashing neon lights screamed out the various entertainment on offer, while scantily clad women sat unabashed in shop windows waiting for business opportunities."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199222_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199222-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p>Koschmider had converted a couple of strip clubs in the district into music venues, and he initially placed the Beatles at the <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles_in_Hamburg" title="The Beatles in Hamburg">Indra Club</a>. After closing Indra due to noise complaints, he moved them to the <a href="/wiki/Kaiserkeller" title="Kaiserkeller">Kaiserkeller</a> in October.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199223_19-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199223-19">[19]</a></sup> When he learned they had been performing at the rival <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Top_Ten_Club" title="Top Ten Club">Top Ten Club</a> in breach of their contract, he gave them one month's termination notice,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199224,_33_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199224,_33-20">[20]</a></sup> and reported the underage Harrison, who had obtained permission to stay in Hamburg by lying to the German authorities about his age.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould200788_21-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould200788-21">[21]</a></sup> The authorities arranged for Harrison's deportation in late November.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199224_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199224-22">[22]</a></sup> One week later, Koschmider had McCartney and Best arrested for arson after they set fire to a condom in a concrete corridor; the authorities deported them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199224–25_23-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199224–25-23">[23]</a></sup> Lennon returned to Liverpool in early December, while Sutcliffe remained in Hamburg until late February with his German fiancée <a href="/wiki/Astrid_Kirchherr" title="Astrid Kirchherr">Astrid Kirchherr</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199225_24-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199225-24">[24]</a></sup> who took the first semi-professional photos of the Beatles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpitz2005222–224_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpitz2005222–224-25">[25]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the next two years, the Beatles were resident for periods in Hamburg, where they used <a href="/wiki/Phenmetrazine" title="Phenmetrazine">Preludin</a> both recreationally and to maintain their energy through all-night performances.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiles199766–67_26-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiles199766–67-26">[26]</a></sup> In 1961, during their second Hamburg engagement, Kirchherr cut Sutcliffe's hair in the "<a href="/wiki/Exi_(subculture)" title="Exi (subculture)">exi</a>" (existentialist) style, later adopted by the other Beatles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199232_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199232-27">[27]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiles199776_28-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiles199776-28">[28]</a></sup> Later on, Sutcliffe decided to leave the band early that year and resume his art studies in Germany. McCartney took over bass.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould200789,_94_29-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould200789,_94-29">[29]</a></sup> Producer <a href="/wiki/Bert_Kaempfert" title="Bert Kaempfert">Bert Kaempfert</a> contracted what was now a four-piece group until June 1962, and he used them as <a href="/wiki/Tony_Sheridan" title="Tony Sheridan">Tony Sheridan</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Backup_band" title="Backup band">backing band</a> on a series of recordings for <a href="/wiki/Polydor_Records" title="Polydor Records">Polydor Records</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGilliland1969show_27,_track_4_15-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGilliland1969show_27,_track_4-15">[15]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpitz2005249–251_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpitz2005249–251-30">[30]</a></sup> As part of the sessions, the Beatles were signed to Polydor for one year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn2013450_31-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn2013450-31">[31]</a></sup> Credited to "Tony Sheridan &amp; the Beat Brothers", the single "<a href="/wiki/My_Bonnie" title="My Bonnie">My Bonnie</a>", recorded in June 1961 and released four months later, reached number 32 on the <i><a href="/wiki/Musikmarkt" title="Musikmarkt">Musikmarkt</a></i> chart.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEverett2001100_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEverett2001100-32">[32]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the Beatles completed their second Hamburg residency, they enjoyed increasing popularity in Liverpool with the growing <a href="/wiki/Beat_music" title="Beat music">Merseybeat</a> movement. However, they were growing tired of the monotony of numerous appearances at the same clubs night after night.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199233_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199233-33">[33]</a></sup> In November 1961, during one of the group's frequent performances at <a href="/wiki/The_Cavern_Club" title="The Cavern Club">the Cavern Club</a>, they encountered <a href="/wiki/Brian_Epstein" title="Brian Epstein">Brian Epstein</a>, a local record-store owner and music columnist.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiles199784–87_34-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiles199784–87-34">[34]</a></sup> He later recalled: "I immediately liked what I heard. They were fresh, and they were honest, and they had what I thought was a sort of presence ... [a] star quality."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199234–35_35-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199234–35-35">[35]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="First_EMI_recordings">First EMI recordings</span></h4>
<p>Epstein courted the band over the next couple of months, and they appointed him as their manager in January 1962.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiles199784–88_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiles199784–88-36">[36]</a></sup> Throughout early and mid-1962, Epstein sought to free the Beatles from their contractual obligations to Bert Kaempfert Productions. He eventually negotiated a one-month early release in exchange for one last recording session in Hamburg.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWinn200810_37-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWinn200810-37">[37]</a></sup> On their return to Germany in April, a distraught Kirchherr met them at the airport with news of Sutcliffe's death the previous day from a <a href="/wiki/Intracerebral_hemorrhage" title="Intracerebral hemorrhage">brain haemorrhage</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199256_38-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199256-38">[38]</a></sup> Epstein began negotiations with record labels for a recording contract. To secure a UK record contract, Epstein negotiated an early end to the band's contract with Polydor, in exchange for more recordings backing Tony Sheridan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn2013612,_629_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn2013612,_629-39">[39]</a></sup> After a New Year's Day audition, <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles%27_Decca_audition" title="The Beatles' Decca audition">Decca Records rejected the band</a>, saying, "Guitar groups are on the way out, Mr. Epstein."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Beatles200067_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Beatles200067-40">[40]</a></sup> However, three months later, producer <a href="/wiki/George_Martin" title="George Martin">George Martin</a> signed the Beatles to <a href="/wiki/EMI" title="EMI">EMI</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Parlophone" title="Parlophone">Parlophone</a> label.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199256_38-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199256-38">[38]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Abbey_Rd_Studios.jpg"><img alt="A flight of stone steps leads from an asphalt car park up to the main entrance of a white two-story building. The ground floor has two sash windows, the first floor has three shorter sash windows. Two more windows are visible at basement level. The decorative stonework around the doors and windows is painted grey." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2400" data-file-width="3200" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Abbey_Rd_Studios.jpg/220px-Abbey_Rd_Studios.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Abbey_Rd_Studios.jpg/330px-Abbey_Rd_Studios.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Abbey_Rd_Studios.jpg/440px-Abbey_Rd_Studios.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Abbey_Rd_Studios.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Main entrance at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/EMI_Studios" title="EMI Studios">EMI Studios</a> (now Abbey Road Studios, pictured 2007)</div></div></div>
<p>Martin's first recording session with the Beatles took place at <a href="/wiki/Abbey_Road_Studios" title="Abbey Road Studios">EMI Recording Studios</a> (later Abbey Road Studios) in London on 6 June 1962.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199259_41-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199259-41">[41]</a></sup> He immediately complained to Epstein about Best's drumming and suggested they use a <a href="/wiki/Session_musician" title="Session musician">session drummer</a> in his place.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpitz2005318,_322_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpitz2005318,_322-42">[42]</a></sup> Already contemplating Best's dismissal,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiles199849–50_43-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiles199849–50-43">[43]</a></sup> the Beatles replaced him in mid-August with <a href="/wiki/Ringo_Starr" title="Ringo Starr">Ringo Starr</a>, who left <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rory_Storm_and_the_Hurricanes" title="Rory Storm and the Hurricanes">Rory Storm and the Hurricanes</a> to join them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199259_41-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199259-41">[41]</a></sup> A 4 September session at EMI yielded a recording of "<a href="/wiki/Love_Me_Do" title="Love Me Do">Love Me Do</a>" featuring Starr on drums, but a dissatisfied Martin hired drummer <a href="/wiki/Andy_White_(drummer)" title="Andy White (drummer)">Andy White</a> for the band's third session a week later, which produced recordings of "Love Me Do", "<a href="/wiki/Please_Please_Me_(song)" title="Please Please Me (song)">Please Please Me</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/P.S._I_Love_You_(Beatles_song)" title="P.S. I Love You (Beatles song)">P.S. I Love You</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199259_41-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199259-41">[41]</a></sup>
</p><p>Martin initially selected the Starr version of "Love Me Do" for the band's first single, though subsequent re-pressings featured the White version, with Starr on tambourine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199259_41-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199259-41">[41]</a></sup> Released in early October, "Love Me Do" peaked at number seventeen on the <i><a href="/wiki/Record_Retailer" title="Record Retailer">Record Retailer</a></i> chart.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199259–60_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199259–60-44">[44]</a></sup> Their television debut came later that month with a live performance on the regional news programme <i><a href="/wiki/Granada_Reports" title="Granada Reports">People and Places</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199281,_355_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199281,_355-45">[45]</a></sup> After Martin suggested rerecording "Please Please Me" at a faster tempo,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Beatles200090_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Beatles200090-46">[46]</a></sup> a studio session in late November yielded that recording,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199262,_84_47-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199262,_84-47">[47]</a></sup> of which Martin accurately predicted, "You've just made your first No. 1."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a875_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a875-48">[48]</a></sup>
</p><p>In December 1962, the Beatles concluded their fifth and final Hamburg residency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199262,_86_49-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199262,_86-49">[49]</a></sup> By 1963, they had agreed that all four band members would contribute vocals to their albums – including Starr, despite his restricted vocal range, to validate his standing in the group.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007191_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007191-50">[50]</a></sup> Lennon and McCartney had established <a href="/wiki/Lennon%E2%80%93McCartney" title="Lennon–McCartney">a songwriting partnership</a>, and as the band's success grew, their dominant collaboration limited Harrison's opportunities as a <a href="/wiki/Lead_vocalist" title="Lead vocalist">lead vocalist</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a494_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a494-51">[51]</a></sup> Epstein, to maximise the Beatles' commercial potential, encouraged them to adopt a professional approach to performing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007128,_133–134_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007128,_133–134-52">[52]</a></sup> Lennon recalled him saying, "Look, if you really want to get in these bigger places, you're going to have to change – stop eating on stage, stop swearing, stop smoking ...."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Beatles200067_40-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Beatles200067-40">[40]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[nb 1]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="1963.E2.80.931966:_Beatlemania_and_touring_years"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1963–1966:_Beatlemania_and_touring_years">1963–1966: Beatlemania and touring years</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Beatlemania" title="Beatlemania">Beatlemania</a></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Please_Please_Me_and_With_the_Beatles"><i>Please Please Me</i> and <i>With the Beatles</i></span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Beatles_logo.svg"><img alt="The logo of the English rock band the Beatles" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="261" data-file-width="512" decoding="async" height="76" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/The_Beatles_logo.svg/150px-The_Beatles_logo.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/The_Beatles_logo.svg/225px-The_Beatles_logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/The_Beatles_logo.svg/300px-The_Beatles_logo.svg.png 2x" width="150"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Beatles_logo.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The band's logo was designed by <a href="/wiki/Ivor_Arbiter" title="Ivor Arbiter">Ivor Arbiter</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWomack200776_54-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWomack200776-54">[53]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>On 11 February 1963, the Beatles recorded ten songs during a single studio session for their debut LP, <i><a href="/wiki/Please_Please_Me" title="Please Please Me">Please Please Me</a></i>. It was supplemented by the four tracks already released on their first two singles. Martin considered recording the LP live at The Cavern Club, but after deciding that the building's acoustics were inadequate, he elected to simulate a "live" album with minimal production in "a single marathon session at Abbey Road".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007147_55-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007147-55">[54]</a></sup> After the moderate success of "Love Me Do", the single "Please Please Me" was released in January 1963, two months ahead of the album. It reached number one on every UK chart except <i>Record Retailer</i>, where it peaked at number two.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199288,_351_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199288,_351-56">[55]</a></sup>
</p><p>Recalling how the Beatles "rushed to deliver a debut album, bashing out <i>Please Please Me</i> in a day", <a href="/wiki/AllMusic" title="AllMusic">AllMusic</a> critic <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Thomas_Erlewine" title="Stephen Thomas Erlewine">Stephen Thomas Erlewine</a> wrote: "Decades after its release, the album still sounds fresh, precisely because of its intense origins."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Please_Please_Me_AllMusic_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-Please_Please_Me_AllMusic-57">[56]</a></sup> Lennon said little thought went into composition at the time; he and McCartney were "just writing songs <i>à la</i> <a href="/wiki/The_Everly_Brothers" title="The Everly Brothers">Everly Brothers</a>, <i>à la</i> Buddy Holly, pop songs with no more thought of them than that – to create a sound. And the words were almost irrelevant."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESheff1981129_58-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESheff1981129-58">[57]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1097025294">.mw-parser-output .side-box{margin:4px 0;box-sizing:border-box;border:1px solid #aaa;font-size:88%;line-height:1.25em;background-color:#f9f9f9}.mw-parser-output .side-box-abovebelow,.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{padding:0.25em 0.9em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-image{padding:2px 0 2px 0.9em;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-imageright{padding:2px 0.9em 2px 0;text-align:center}@media(min-width:500px){.mw-parser-output .side-box-flex{display:flex;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{flex:1}}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .side-box{width:238px}.mw-parser-output .side-box-right{clear:right;float:right;margin-left:1em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-left{margin-right:1em}}</style><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096940132">.mw-parser-output .listen .side-box-text{line-height:1.1em}.mw-parser-output .listen-plain{border:none;background:transparent}.mw-parser-output .listen-embedded{width:100%;margin:0;border-width:1px 0 0 0;background:transparent}.mw-parser-output .listen-header{padding:2px}.mw-parser-output .listen-embedded .listen-header{padding:2px 0}.mw-parser-output .listen-file-header{padding:4px 0}.mw-parser-output .listen .description{padding-top:2px}.mw-parser-output .listen .mw-tmh-player{max-width:100%}@media(max-width:719px){.mw-parser-output .listen{clear:both}}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .listen:not(.listen-noimage){width:320px}.mw-parser-output .listen-left{overflow:visible;float:left}.mw-parser-output .listen-center{float:none;margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto}}</style><div class="side-box side-box-right listen noprint">
<div class="side-box-flex">
<div class="side-box-image"><div class="center"><div class="floatnone"><img alt="" data-file-height="160" data-file-width="160" decoding="async" height="50" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/50px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/75px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/100px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png 2x" width="50"/></div></div></div>
<div class="side-box-text plainlist"><div class="haudio">
<div class="listen-file-header"><a href="/wiki/File:She_Loves_You_(Beatles_song_-_sample).ogg" title="File:She Loves You (Beatles song - sample).ogg">"She Loves You"</a></div>
<div><audio controls="" data-durationhint="13" data-mwprovider="local" data-mwtitle="She_Loves_You_(Beatles_song_-_sample).ogg" id="mwe_player_0" preload="none" style="width:232px;" width="232"><source data-bandwidth="59323" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" data-title="Original Ogg file (59 kbps)" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/0/0c/She_Loves_You_%28Beatles_song_-_sample%29.ogg" type='audio/ogg; codecs="vorbis"'/><source data-bandwidth="160448" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="MP3" data-title="MP3" data-transcodekey="mp3" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/transcoded/0/0c/She_Loves_You_%28Beatles_song_-_sample%29.ogg/She_Loves_You_%28Beatles_song_-_sample%29.ogg.mp3" type="audio/mpeg"/><track data-dir="ltr" kind="subtitles" label="English ‪(en)‬" src="/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;title=File%3AShe_Loves_You_%28Beatles_song_-_sample%29.ogg&amp;lang=en&amp;trackformat=vtt" srclang="en" type="text/vtt"/></audio></div>
<div class="description">Sample of "<a href="/wiki/She_Loves_You" title="She Loves You">She Loves You</a>". The song's repeated use of "yeah" exclamations became a signature phrase for the group at the time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDavies1968200_59-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDavies1968200-59">[58]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn198835_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn198835-60">[59]</a></sup></div></div></div></div>
<div class="side-box-abovebelow"><hr/><i class="selfreference">Problems playing this file? See <a href="/wiki/Help:Media" title="Help:Media">media help</a>.</i></div>
</div>
<p>Released in March 1963, <i>Please Please Me</i> was the first of eleven consecutive Beatles albums released in the United Kingdom to reach number one.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199290,_351_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199290,_351-61">[60]</a></sup> The band's third single, "<a href="/wiki/From_Me_to_You" title="From Me to You">From Me to You</a>", came out in April and began an almost unbroken string of seventeen British number-one singles, including all but one of the eighteen they released over the next six years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199289,_350–351_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199289,_350–351-62">[61]</a></sup> Issued in August, their fourth single, "<a href="/wiki/She_Loves_You" title="She Loves You">She Loves You</a>", achieved the fastest sales of any record in the UK up to that time, selling three-quarters of a million copies in under four weeks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007159_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007159-63">[62]</a></sup> It became their first single to sell a million copies, and remained the biggest-selling record in the UK until 1978.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a990_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a990-64">[63]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[nb 2]</a></sup>
</p><p>The success brought increased media exposure, to which the Beatles responded with an irreverent and comical attitude that defied the expectations of pop musicians at the time, inspiring even more interest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007166–169_66-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007166–169-66">[64]</a></sup> The band toured the UK three times in the first half of the year: a four-week tour that began in February, the Beatles' first nationwide, preceded three-week tours in March and May–June.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199290,_98–105,_109–112_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199290,_98–105,_109–112-67">[65]</a></sup> As their popularity spread, a frenzied adulation of the group took hold. On 13 October, the Beatles starred on <i><a href="/wiki/Tonight_at_the_London_Palladium" title="Tonight at the London Palladium">Sunday Night at the London Palladium</a></i>, the UK's top variety show.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPawlowski1990146_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPawlowski1990146-68">[66]</a></sup> Their performance was televised live and watched by 15 million viewers. One national paper's headlines in the following days coined the term "<a href="/wiki/Beatlemania" title="Beatlemania">Beatlemania</a>" to describe the riotous enthusiasm by screaming fans who greeted the band – and it stuck.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPawlowski1990146_68-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPawlowski1990146-68">[66]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpitz2005444–445_69-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpitz2005444–445-69">[67]</a></sup> Although not billed as tour leaders, the Beatles overshadowed American acts <a href="/wiki/Tommy_Roe" title="Tommy Roe">Tommy Roe</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chris_Montez" title="Chris Montez">Chris Montez</a> during the February engagements and assumed top billing "by audience demand", something no British act had previously accomplished while touring with artists from the US.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199288_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199288-70">[68]</a></sup> A similar situation arose during their May–June <a href="/wiki/Roy_Orbison/The_Beatles_Tour" title="Roy Orbison/The Beatles Tour">tour with Roy Orbison</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199290_71-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199290-71">[69]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Beatles_and_Lill-Babs_1963.jpg"><img alt="Paul McCartney, George Harrison, Swedish pop singer Lill-Babs and John Lennon on the set of the Swedish television show Drop-In in 1963" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1436" data-file-width="1844" decoding="async" height="171" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/The_Beatles_and_Lill-Babs_1963.jpg/220px-The_Beatles_and_Lill-Babs_1963.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/The_Beatles_and_Lill-Babs_1963.jpg/330px-The_Beatles_and_Lill-Babs_1963.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/The_Beatles_and_Lill-Babs_1963.jpg/440px-The_Beatles_and_Lill-Babs_1963.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Beatles_and_Lill-Babs_1963.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>McCartney, Harrison, Swedish pop singer <a href="/wiki/Lill-Babs" title="Lill-Babs">Lill-Babs</a> and Lennon on the set of the <a href="/wiki/Sveriges_Television" title="Sveriges Television">Swedish television</a> show <i>Drop-In</i>, 30 October 1963<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiles199886_72-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiles199886-72">[70]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>In late October, the Beatles began a five-day tour of Sweden, their first time abroad since the final Hamburg engagement of December 1962.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a1088_73-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a1088-73">[71]</a></sup> On their return to the UK on 31 October, several hundred screaming fans greeted them in heavy rain at <a href="/wiki/Heathrow_Airport" title="Heathrow Airport">Heathrow Airport</a>. Around 50 to 100 journalists and photographers, as well as representatives from the <a href="/wiki/BBC_Television" title="BBC Television">BBC</a>, also joined the airport reception, the first of more than 100 such events.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199292–93_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199292–93-74">[72]</a></sup> The next day, the band began its fourth tour of Britain within nine months, this one scheduled for six weeks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992127–133_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992127–133-75">[73]</a></sup> In mid-November, as Beatlemania intensified, police resorted to using high-pressure water hoses to control the crowd before a concert in Plymouth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDavies1968184–185_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDavies1968184–185-76">[74]</a></sup>
</p><p><i>Please Please Me</i> maintained the top position on the <i>Record Retailer</i> chart for 30 weeks, only to be displaced by its follow-up, <i><a href="/wiki/With_the_Beatles" title="With the Beatles">With the Beatles</a></i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199290,_92,_100_77-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199290,_92,_100-77">[75]</a></sup> which EMI released on 22 November to record advance orders of 270,000 copies. The LP topped a half-million albums sold in one week.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn199293_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn199293-78">[76]</a></sup> Recorded between July and October, <i>With the Beatles</i> made better use of studio production techniques than its predecessor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007187_79-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007187-79">[77]</a></sup> It held the top spot for 21 weeks with a chart life of 40 weeks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a1161_80-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a1161-80">[78]</a></sup> Erlewine described the LP as "a sequel of the highest order – one that betters the original".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[79]</a></sup>
</p><p>In a reversal of then standard practice, EMI released the album ahead of the impending single "<a href="/wiki/I_Want_to_Hold_Your_Hand" title="I Want to Hold Your Hand">I Want to Hold Your Hand</a>", with the song excluded to maximise the single's sales.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007187–188_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007187–188-82">[80]</a></sup> The album caught the attention of music critic <a href="/wiki/William_Mann_(critic)" title="William Mann (critic)">William Mann</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Times" title="The Times">The Times</a></i>, who suggested that Lennon and McCartney were "the outstanding English composers of 1963".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007187_79-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007187-79">[77]</a></sup> The newspaper published a series of articles in which Mann offered detailed analyses of the music, lending it respectability.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a1162_83-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a1162-83">[81]</a></sup> <i>With the Beatles</i> became the second album in UK chart history to sell a million copies, a figure previously reached only by the 1958 <a href="/wiki/South_Pacific_(soundtrack)" title="South Pacific (soundtrack)"><i>South Pacific</i> soundtrack</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000b978_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000b978-84">[82]</a></sup> When writing the <a href="/wiki/Liner_notes" title="Liner notes">sleeve notes</a> for the album, the band's press officer, <a href="/wiki/Tony_Barrow" title="Tony Barrow">Tony Barrow</a>, used the superlative the "fabulous foursome", which the media widely adopted as "the Fab Four".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a402_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a402-85">[83]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="First_visit_to_the_United_States_and_the_British_Invasion">First visit to the United States and the British Invasion</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/British_Invasion" title="British Invasion">British Invasion</a></div>
<p>EMI's American subsidiary, <a href="/wiki/Capitol_Records" title="Capitol Records">Capitol Records</a>, hindered the Beatles' releases in the United States for more than a year by initially declining to issue their music, including their first three singles. Concurrent negotiations with the independent US label <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vee-Jay" title="Vee-Jay">Vee-Jay</a> led to the release of some, but not all, of the songs in 1963.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992350_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992350-86">[84]</a></sup> Vee-Jay finished preparation for the album <i><a href="/wiki/Introducing..._The_Beatles" title="Introducing... The Beatles">Introducing... The Beatles</a></i>, comprising most of the songs of Parlophone's <i>Please Please Me</i>, but a management shake-up led to the album not being released.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[nb 3]</a></sup> After it emerged that the label did not report royalties on their sales, the licence that Vee-Jay had signed with EMI was voided.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpizer200440_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpizer200440-89">[86]</a></sup> A new licence was granted to the <a href="/wiki/Swan_Records" title="Swan Records">Swan</a> label for the single "She Loves You". The record received some airplay in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tidewater_region" title="Tidewater region">Tidewater area</a> of Virginia from Gene Loving of radio station <a href="/wiki/WGH_(AM)" title="WGH (AM)">WGH</a> and was featured on the "Rate-a-Record" segment of <i><a href="/wiki/American_Bandstand" title="American Bandstand">American Bandstand</a></i>, but it failed to catch on nationally.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a225–226,_228,_1118–1122_90-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a225–226,_228,_1118–1122-90">[87]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Beatles_in_America.JPG"><img alt="A black-and-white image of four men standing in front of a crowd of people at the bottom of an aeroplane staircase" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2526" data-file-width="3578" decoding="async" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/The_Beatles_in_America.JPG/220px-The_Beatles_in_America.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/The_Beatles_in_America.JPG/330px-The_Beatles_in_America.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/The_Beatles_in_America.JPG/440px-The_Beatles_in_America.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Beatles_in_America.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Beatles arriving at <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_International_Airport" title="John F. Kennedy International Airport">John F. Kennedy International Airport</a>, 7 February 1964</div></div></div>
<p>Epstein brought a demo copy of "<a href="/wiki/I_Want_to_Hold_Your_Hand" title="I Want to Hold Your Hand">I Want to Hold Your Hand</a>" to Capitol's <a href="/wiki/Brown_Meggs" title="Brown Meggs">Brown Meggs</a>, who signed the band and arranged for a $40,000 US marketing campaign. American chart success began after disc jockey Carroll James of AM radio station <a href="/wiki/WQOF" title="WQOF">WWDC</a>, in Washington, DC, obtained a copy of the British single "I Want to Hold Your Hand" in mid-December 1963 and began playing it on-air.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[88]</a></sup> Taped copies of the song soon circulated among other radio stations throughout the US. This caused an increase in demand, leading Capitol to bring forward the release of "I Want to Hold Your Hand" by three weeks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEverett2001206_92-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEverett2001206-92">[89]</a></sup> Issued on 26 December, with the band's previously scheduled debut there just weeks away, "I Want to Hold Your Hand" sold a million copies, becoming a number-one hit in the US by mid-January.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992136,_350_93-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992136,_350-93">[90]</a></sup> In its wake Vee-Jay released <i>Introducing... The Beatles</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpizer200496_94-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpizer200496-94">[91]</a></sup> along with Capitol's debut album, <i><a href="/wiki/Meet_the_Beatles!" title="Meet the Beatles!">Meet the Beatles!</a></i>, while Swan reactivated production of "She Loves You".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDavies1968218_95-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDavies1968218-95">[92]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Beatles_performing_at_The_Ed_Sullivan_Show_(cropped_2).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2128" data-file-width="3126" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/The_Beatles_performing_at_The_Ed_Sullivan_Show_%28cropped_2%29.jpg/220px-The_Beatles_performing_at_The_Ed_Sullivan_Show_%28cropped_2%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/The_Beatles_performing_at_The_Ed_Sullivan_Show_%28cropped_2%29.jpg/330px-The_Beatles_performing_at_The_Ed_Sullivan_Show_%28cropped_2%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/The_Beatles_performing_at_The_Ed_Sullivan_Show_%28cropped_2%29.jpg/440px-The_Beatles_performing_at_The_Ed_Sullivan_Show_%28cropped_2%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Beatles_performing_at_The_Ed_Sullivan_Show_(cropped_2).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Beatles performing on <i><a href="/wiki/The_Ed_Sullivan_Show" title="The Ed Sullivan Show">The Ed Sullivan Show</a>,</i> February 1964</div></div></div>
<p>On 7 February 1964, the Beatles departed from Heathrow with an estimated 4,000 fans waving and screaming as the aircraft took off.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpitz2005457_96-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpitz2005457-96">[93]</a></sup> Upon landing at New York's <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_International_Airport" title="John F. Kennedy International Airport">John F. Kennedy Airport</a>, an uproarious crowd estimated at 3,000 greeted them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpitz2005459_97-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpitz2005459-97">[94]</a></sup> They gave their first live US television performance two days later on <i><a href="/wiki/The_Beatles_on_The_Ed_Sullivan_Show" title="The Beatles on The Ed Sullivan Show">The Ed Sullivan Show</a></i>, watched by approximately 73 million viewers in over 23 million households,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992137_98-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992137-98">[95]</a></sup> or 34 per cent of the American population. Biographer Jonathan Gould writes that, according to the <a href="/wiki/Nielsen_ratings" title="Nielsen ratings">Nielsen</a> rating service, it was "the largest audience that had ever been recorded for an American television <span title="American English-language text"><span lang="en-US">program</span></span>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould20073_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould20073-99">[96]</a></sup> The next morning, the Beatles awoke to a largely negative critical consensus in the US,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpitz2005473–474_100-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpitz2005473–474-100">[97]</a></sup> but a day later at their first US concert, Beatlemania erupted at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Washington_Coliseum" title="Washington Coliseum">Washington Coliseum</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a1134–1135_101-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a1134–1135-101">[98]</a></sup> Back in New York the following day, the Beatles met with another strong reception during two shows at <a href="/wiki/Carnegie_Hall" title="Carnegie Hall">Carnegie Hall</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992137_98-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992137-98">[95]</a></sup> The band flew to Florida, where they appeared on <i>The Ed Sullivan Show</i> a second time, again before 70 million viewers, before returning to the UK on 22 February.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992137,_146–147_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992137,_146–147-102">[99]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Beatles' first visit to the US took place when the nation was still mourning the <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy" title="Assassination of John F. Kennedy">assassination of President John F. Kennedy</a> the previous November.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gimore_(RS_Beatles/Dylan/60s)_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gimore_(RS_Beatles/Dylan/60s)-103">[100]</a></sup> Commentators often suggest that for many, particularly the young, the Beatles' performances reignited the sense of excitement and possibility that momentarily faded in the wake of the assassination, and helped pave the way for the revolutionary social changes to come later in the decade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[101]</a></sup> Their hairstyle, unusually long for the era and mocked by many adults,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGilliland1969show_27,_track_4_15-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGilliland1969show_27,_track_4-15">[15]</a></sup> became an emblem of rebellion to the burgeoning youth culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007345_105-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007345-105">[102]</a></sup>
</p><p>The group's popularity generated unprecedented interest in British music, and many other UK acts subsequently made their American debuts, successfully touring over the next three years in what was termed the <a href="/wiki/British_Invasion" title="British Invasion">British Invasion</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould20079,_250,_285_106-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould20079,_250,_285-106">[103]</a></sup> The Beatles' success in the US opened the door for a successive string of British <a href="/wiki/Beat_music" title="Beat music">beat groups</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pop_music" title="Pop music">pop</a> acts such as <a href="/wiki/The_Dave_Clark_Five" title="The Dave Clark Five">the Dave Clark Five</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Animals" title="The Animals">the Animals</a>, <a href="/wiki/Petula_Clark" title="Petula Clark">Petula Clark</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Kinks" title="The Kinks">the Kinks</a>, and <a href="/wiki/The_Rolling_Stones" title="The Rolling Stones">the Rolling Stones</a> to achieve success in America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Puterbaugh_(British_Invasion)_107-0"><a href="#cite_note-Puterbaugh_(British_Invasion)-107">[104]</a></sup> During the week of 4 April 1964, the Beatles held twelve positions on the <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100"><i>Billboard</i> Hot 100</a> singles chart, including the top five.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992138_108-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992138-108">[105]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[nb 4]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="A_Hard_Day.27s_Night"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="A_Hard_Day's_Night"><i>A Hard Day's Night</i></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/A_Hard_Day%27s_Night_(film)" title="A Hard Day's Night (film)">A Hard Day's Night (film)</a></div>
<p>Capitol Records' lack of interest throughout 1963 did not go unnoticed, and a competitor, <a href="/wiki/United_Artists_Records" title="United Artists Records">United Artists Records</a>, encouraged <a href="/wiki/United_Artists" title="United Artists">its film division</a> to offer the Beatles a three-motion-picture deal, primarily for the commercial potential of the soundtracks in the US.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a483–484_111-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a483–484-111">[107]</a></sup> Directed by <a href="/wiki/Richard_Lester" title="Richard Lester">Richard Lester</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/A_Hard_Day%27s_Night_(film)" title="A Hard Day's Night (film)">A Hard Day's Night</a></i> involved the band for six weeks in March–April 1964 as they played themselves in a musical comedy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007230–232_112-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007230–232-112">[108]</a></sup> The film premiered in London and New York in July and August, respectively, and was an international success, with some critics drawing a comparison with the <a href="/wiki/Marx_Brothers" title="Marx Brothers">Marx Brothers</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a489–490_113-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a489–490-113">[109]</a></sup>
</p><p>United Artists released a <a href="/wiki/A_Hard_Day%27s_Night_(album)#North_American_release" title="A Hard Day's Night (album)">full soundtrack album</a> for the North American market, combining Beatles songs and Martin's orchestral score; elsewhere, the group's third studio LP, <i><a href="/wiki/A_Hard_Day%27s_Night_(album)" title="A Hard Day's Night (album)">A Hard Day's Night</a></i>, contained songs from the film on side one and other new recordings on side two.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn198847_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn198847-114">[110]</a></sup> According to Erlewine, the album saw them "truly coming into their own as a band. All of the disparate influences on their first two albums coalesced into a bright, joyous, original sound, filled with ringing guitars and irresistible melodies."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[111]</a></sup> That "ringing guitar" sound was primarily the product of Harrison's <a href="/wiki/Rickenbacker_360/12" title="Rickenbacker 360/12">12-string electric Rickenbacker</a>, a prototype given to him by the manufacturer, which made its debut on the record.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007286–287_116-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007286–287-116">[112]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[nb 5]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="1964_world_tour.2C_meeting_Bob_Dylan.2C_and_stand_on_civil_rights"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1964_world_tour,_meeting_Bob_Dylan,_and_stand_on_civil_rights">1964 world tour, meeting Bob Dylan, and stand on civil rights</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Paul,_George_%26_John.png"><img alt="Paul McCartney, George Harrison and John Lennon of the Beatles performing on Dutch TV in 1964" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="329" data-file-width="500" decoding="async" height="171" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Paul%2C_George_%26_John.png/260px-Paul%2C_George_%26_John.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Paul%2C_George_%26_John.png/390px-Paul%2C_George_%26_John.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/04/Paul%2C_George_%26_John.png 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Paul,_George_%26_John.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>McCartney, Harrison and Lennon performing on Dutch TV in 1964</div></div></div>
<p>Touring internationally in June and July, the Beatles staged 37 shows over 27 days in Denmark, the Netherlands, Hong Kong, Australia and New Zealand.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992161–165_118-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992161–165-118">[113]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[nb 6]</a></sup> In August and September, they returned to the US, with a 30-concert tour of 23 cities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007249_121-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007249-121">[115]</a></sup> Generating intense interest once again, the month-long tour attracted between 10,000 and 20,000 fans to each 30-minute performance in cities from San Francisco to New York.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007249_121-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007249-121">[115]</a></sup>
</p><p>In August, journalist <a href="/wiki/Al_Aronowitz" title="Al Aronowitz">Al Aronowitz</a> arranged for the Beatles to meet <a href="/wiki/Bob_Dylan" title="Bob Dylan">Bob Dylan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007252_122-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007252-122">[116]</a></sup> Visiting the band in their New York hotel suite, Dylan introduced them to <a href="/wiki/Cannabis_(drug)" title="Cannabis (drug)">cannabis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiles1997185_123-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiles1997185-123">[117]</a></sup> Gould points out the musical and cultural significance of this meeting, before which the musicians' respective fanbases were "perceived as inhabiting two separate subcultural worlds": Dylan's audience of "college kids with artistic or intellectual leanings, a dawning political and social idealism, and a mildly <a href="/wiki/Bohemian_style" title="Bohemian style">bohemian style</a>" contrasted with their fans, "veritable '<a href="/wiki/Teenybopper" title="Teenybopper">teenyboppers</a>' – kids in high school or grade school whose lives were totally wrapped up in the commercialised popular culture of television, radio, pop records, fan magazines, and teen fashion. To many of Dylan's followers in the <a href="/wiki/Folk_music" title="Folk music">folk music</a> scene, the Beatles were seen as idolaters, not idealists."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007252–253_124-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007252–253-124">[118]</a></sup>
</p><p>Within six months of the meeting, according to Gould, "Lennon would be making records on which he openly imitated Dylan's nasal drone, brittle strum, and introspective vocal persona"; and six months after that, Dylan began performing with a backing band and <a href="/wiki/Electric_Dylan_controversy" title="Electric Dylan controversy">electric instrumentation</a>, and "dressed in the height of Mod fashion".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007253_125-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007253-125">[119]</a></sup> As a result, Gould continues, the traditional division between folk and rock enthusiasts "nearly evaporated", as the Beatles' fans began to mature in their outlook and Dylan's audience embraced the new, youth-driven pop culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007253_125-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007253-125">[119]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the 1964 US tour, the group were confronted with <a href="/wiki/Racial_segregation_in_the_United_States" title="Racial segregation in the United States">racial segregation</a> in the country at the time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Integration_(BBC)_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-Integration_(BBC)-126">[120]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Integration_(Mirken)_127-0"><a href="#cite_note-Integration_(Mirken)-127">[121]</a></sup> When informed that the venue for their 11 September concert, the <a href="/wiki/Gator_Bowl_Stadium" title="Gator Bowl Stadium">Gator Bowl</a> in <a href="/wiki/Jacksonville,_Florida" title="Jacksonville, Florida">Jacksonville, Florida</a>, was segregated, the Beatles said they would refuse to perform unless the audience was integrated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992171_128-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992171-128">[122]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Integration_(BBC)_126-1"><a href="#cite_note-Integration_(BBC)-126">[120]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Integration_(Mirken)_127-1"><a href="#cite_note-Integration_(Mirken)-127">[121]</a></sup> Lennon stated: "We never play to segregated audiences and we aren't going to start now ... I'd sooner lose our appearance money."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Integration_(BBC)_126-2"><a href="#cite_note-Integration_(BBC)-126">[120]</a></sup> City officials relented and agreed to allow an integrated show.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Integration_(BBC)_126-3"><a href="#cite_note-Integration_(BBC)-126">[120]</a></sup> The group also cancelled their reservations at the whites-only <a href="/wiki/Hotel_George_Washington_(Jacksonville)" title="Hotel George Washington (Jacksonville)">Hotel George Washington</a> in Jacksonville.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Integration_(Mirken)_127-2"><a href="#cite_note-Integration_(Mirken)-127">[121]</a></sup> For their subsequent US tours in 1965 and 1966, the Beatles included clauses in contracts stipulating that shows be integrated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Integration_(Mirken)_127-3"><a href="#cite_note-Integration_(Mirken)-127">[121]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Integration_(Huffpost)_129-0"><a href="#cite_note-Integration_(Huffpost)-129">[123]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Beatles_for_Sale.2C_Help.21_and_Rubber_Soul"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Beatles_for_Sale,_Help!_and_Rubber_Soul"><i>Beatles for Sale</i>, <i>Help!</i> and <i>Rubber Soul</i></span></h4>
<p>According to Gould, the Beatles' fourth studio LP, <i><a href="/wiki/Beatles_for_Sale" title="Beatles for Sale">Beatles for Sale</a></i>, evidenced a growing conflict between the commercial pressures of their global success and their creative ambitions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007255–256_130-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007255–256-130">[124]</a></sup> They had intended the album, recorded between August and October 1964,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992167–176_131-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992167–176-131">[125]</a></sup> to continue the format established by <i>A Hard Day's Night</i> which, unlike their first two LPs, contained only original songs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007255–256_130-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007255–256-130">[124]</a></sup> They had nearly exhausted their backlog of songs on the previous album, however, and given the challenges constant international touring posed to their songwriting efforts, Lennon admitted, "Material's becoming a hell of a problem".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007256_132-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007256-132">[126]</a></sup> As a result, six covers from their extensive repertoire were chosen to complete the album. Released in early December, its eight original compositions stood out, demonstrating the growing maturity of the <a href="/wiki/Lennon%E2%80%93McCartney" title="Lennon–McCartney">Lennon–McCartney</a> songwriting partnership.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007255–256_130-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007255–256-130">[124]</a></sup>
</p><p>In early 1965, following a dinner with Lennon, Harrison and their wives, Harrison's dentist, John Riley, secretly added <a href="/wiki/Lysergic_acid_diethylamide" title="Lysergic acid diethylamide">LSD</a> to their coffee.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[127]</a></sup> Lennon described the experience: "It was just terrifying, but it was fantastic. I was pretty stunned for a month or two."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007316_134-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007316-134">[128]</a></sup> He and Harrison subsequently became regular users of the drug, joined by Starr on at least one occasion. Harrison's use of <a href="/wiki/Psychedelic_drug" title="Psychedelic drug">psychedelic drugs</a> encouraged his path to meditation and Hinduism. He commented: "For me, it was like a flash.
