The first time I had <a href="/wiki/Lysergic_acid_diethylamide" title="Lysergic acid diethylamide">acid</a>, it just opened up something in my head that was inside of me, and I realised a lot of things. I didn't learn them because I already knew them, but that happened to be the key that opened the door to reveal them. From the moment I had that, I wanted to have it all the time – these thoughts about the yogis and the Himalayas, and <a href="/wiki/Ravi_Shankar" title="Ravi Shankar">Ravi</a>'s music."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[129]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[130]</a></sup> McCartney was initially reluctant to try it, but eventually did so in late 1966.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007317_137-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007317-137">[131]</a></sup> He became the first Beatle to discuss LSD publicly, declaring in a magazine interview that "it opened my eyes" and "made me a better, more honest, more tolerant member of society".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrownGaines2002228_138-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrownGaines2002228-138">[132]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:TrailerUSHelp.jpg"><img alt="The Beatles performing music in a field. In the foreground, the drums are played by Starr (only the top of his head is visible). Beyond him, the other three stand in a column with their guitars. In the rear, Harrison, head down, strikes a chord. In the front, Lennon smiles and gives a little wave toward camera, holding his pick. Between them, McCartney is jocularly about to choke Lennon." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="475" data-file-width="641" decoding="async" height="163" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/TrailerUSHelp.jpg/220px-TrailerUSHelp.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/TrailerUSHelp.jpg/330px-TrailerUSHelp.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/TrailerUSHelp.jpg/440px-TrailerUSHelp.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:TrailerUSHelp.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The US trailer for <i><a href="/wiki/Help!_(film)" title="Help! (film)">Help!</a></i> with (from the rear) Harrison, McCartney, Lennon and (largely obscured) Starr</div></div></div>
<p>Controversy erupted in June 1965 when Queen <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_II" title="Elizabeth II">Elizabeth II</a> appointed all four Beatles Members of the <a href="/wiki/Order_of_the_British_Empire" title="Order of the British Empire">Order of the British Empire</a> (MBE) after Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Harold_Wilson" title="Harold Wilson">Harold Wilson</a> nominated them for the award.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpitz2005556_139-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpitz2005556-139">[133]</a></sup> In protest – the honour was at that time primarily bestowed upon military veterans and civic leaders – some conservative MBE recipients returned their insignia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpitz2005557_140-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpitz2005557-140">[134]</a></sup>
</p><p>In July, the Beatles' second film, <i><a href="/wiki/Help!_(film)" title="Help! (film)">Help!</a></i>, was released, again directed by Lester. Described as "mainly a relentless spoof of <a href="/wiki/Production_of_the_James_Bond_films" title="Production of the James Bond films">Bond</a>",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007275_141-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007275-141">[135]</a></sup> it inspired a mixed response among both reviewers and the band. McCartney said: "<i>Help!</i> was great but it wasn't our film – we were sort of guest stars. It was fun, but basically, as an idea for a film, it was a bit wrong."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007274_142-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007274-142">[136]</a></sup> The soundtrack was dominated by Lennon, who wrote and sang lead on most of its songs, including the two singles: "<a href="/wiki/Help!_(song)" title="Help! (song)">Help!</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/Ticket_to_Ride_(song)" title="Ticket to Ride (song)">Ticket to Ride</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007276–277_143-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007276–277-143">[137]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <i><a href="/wiki/Help!" title="Help!">Help!</a></i> album, the group's fifth studio LP, mirrored <i>A Hard Day's Night</i> by featuring soundtrack songs on side one and additional songs from the same sessions on side two.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn198862_144-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn198862-144">[138]</a></sup> The LP contained all original material save for two covers, "<a href="/wiki/Act_Naturally" title="Act Naturally">Act Naturally</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/Dizzy,_Miss_Lizzy" title="Dizzy, Miss Lizzy">Dizzy Miss Lizzy</a>"; they were the last covers the band would include on an album, except for <i><a href="/wiki/Let_It_Be_(Beatles_album)" title="Let It Be (Beatles album)">Let It Be</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'s</span> brief rendition of the traditional Liverpool folk song "<a href="/wiki/Maggie_May_(folk_song)" title="Maggie May (folk song)">Maggie Mae</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007276–280_145-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007276–280-145">[139]</a></sup> The band expanded their use of vocal overdubs on <i>Help!</i> and incorporated classical instruments into some arrangements, including a string quartet on the pop ballad "<a href="/wiki/Yesterday_(Beatles_song)" title="Yesterday (Beatles song)">Yesterday</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007290–292Lewisohn198859,_62_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007290–292Lewisohn198859,_62-146">[140]</a></sup> Composed by and sung by McCartney – none of the other Beatles perform on the recording<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn198859_147-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn198859-147">[141]</a></sup> – "Yesterday" has inspired the most cover versions of any song ever written.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[142]</a></sup> With <i>Help!</i>, the Beatles became the first rock group to be nominated for a <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Album_of_the_Year" title="Grammy Award for Album of the Year">Grammy Award for Album of the Year</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[143]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Beatles_press_conference_1965.jpg"><img alt="The Beatles at a press conference in August 1965" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="418" data-file-width="585" decoding="async" height="171" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Beatles_press_conference_1965.jpg/240px-Beatles_press_conference_1965.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Beatles_press_conference_1965.jpg/360px-Beatles_press_conference_1965.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Beatles_press_conference_1965.jpg/480px-Beatles_press_conference_1965.jpg 2x" width="240"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Beatles_press_conference_1965.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Beatles at a press conference in <a href="/wiki/Minnesota" title="Minnesota">Minnesota</a> in August 1965, shortly after playing at <a href="/wiki/Shea_Stadium" title="Shea Stadium">Shea Stadium</a> in New York</div></div></div>
<p>The group's third US tour opened with a performance before a world-record crowd of 55,600 at New York's <a href="/wiki/Shea_Stadium" title="Shea Stadium">Shea Stadium</a> on 15 August – "perhaps the most famous of all Beatles' concerts", in Lewisohn's description.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992181_150-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992181-150">[144]</a></sup> A further nine successful concerts followed in other American cities. At a show in Atlanta, the Beatles gave one of the first live performances ever to make use of a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Foldback_(sound_engineering)" title="Foldback (sound engineering)">foldback</a> system of on-stage monitor speakers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[145]</a></sup> Towards the end of the tour, they met with <a href="/wiki/Elvis_Presley" title="Elvis Presley">Elvis Presley</a>, a foundational musical influence on the band, who invited them to his home in <a href="/wiki/Beverly_Hills,_California" title="Beverly Hills, California">Beverly Hills</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a882–883_152-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a882–883-152">[146]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007283–284_153-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007283–284-153">[147]</a></sup>
</p><p>September 1965 saw the launch of an American <a href="/wiki/Saturday-morning_cartoon" title="Saturday-morning cartoon">Saturday-morning cartoon</a> series, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Beatles_(TV_series)" title="The Beatles (TV series)">The Beatles</a></i>, that echoed <i>A Hard Day's Night</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'s</span> slapstick antics over its two-year original run.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcNeil199682_154-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcNeil199682-154">[148]</a></sup> The series was a historical milestone as the first weekly television series to feature animated versions of real, living people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Animators_155-0"><a href="#cite_note-Animators-155">[149]</a></sup>
</p><p>In mid-October, the Beatles entered the recording studio; for the first time when making an album, they had an extended period without other major commitments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992202_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992202-156">[150]</a></sup> Until this time, according to George Martin, "we had been making albums rather like a collection of singles. Now we were really beginning to think about albums as a bit of art on their own."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHertsgaard1995149–150_157-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHertsgaard1995149–150-157">[151]</a></sup> Released in December, <i><a href="/wiki/Rubber_Soul" title="Rubber Soul">Rubber Soul</a></i> was hailed by critics as a major step forward in the maturity and complexity of the band's music.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rubber_Soul_AllMusic_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rubber_Soul_AllMusic-158">[152]</a></sup> Their thematic reach was beginning to expand as they embraced deeper aspects of romance and philosophy, a development that NEMS executive <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Peter_Brown_(music_industry)" title="Peter Brown (music industry)">Peter Brown</a> attributed to the band members' "now habitual use of marijuana".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrownGaines2002181–182_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrownGaines2002181–182-159">[153]</a></sup> Lennon referred to <i>Rubber Soul</i> as "the pot album"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Beatles2000194_160-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Beatles2000194-160">[154]</a></sup> and Starr said: "Grass was really influential in a lot of our changes, especially with the writers. And because they were writing different material, we were playing differently."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Beatles2000194_160-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Beatles2000194-160">[154]</a></sup> After <i>Help!</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s foray into classical music with flutes and strings, Harrison's introduction of a <a href="/wiki/Sitar" title="Sitar">sitar</a> on "<a href="/wiki/Norwegian_Wood_(This_Bird_Has_Flown)" title="Norwegian Wood (This Bird Has Flown)">Norwegian Wood (This Bird Has Flown)</a>" marked a further progression outside the traditional boundaries of popular music. As the lyrics grew more artful, fans began to study them for deeper meaning.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007297–298,_423_161-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007297–298,_423-161">[155]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1097025294" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096940132" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="side-box side-box-right listen noprint">
<div class="side-box-flex">
<div class="side-box-image"><div class="center"><div class="floatnone"><img alt="" data-file-height="160" data-file-width="160" decoding="async" height="50" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/50px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/75px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/100px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png 2x" width="50"/></div></div></div>
<div class="side-box-text plainlist"><div class="haudio">
<div class="listen-file-header"><a href="/wiki/File:Beatles_norwegian_wood.ogg" title="File:Beatles norwegian wood.ogg">"Norwegian Wood (This Bird Has Flown)"</a></div>
<div><audio controls="" data-durationhint="15" data-mwprovider="local" data-mwtitle="Beatles_norwegian_wood.ogg" id="mwe_player_1" preload="none" style="width:232px;" width="232"><source data-bandwidth="73775" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" data-title="Original Ogg file (74 kbps)" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/e/ea/Beatles_norwegian_wood.ogg" type='audio/ogg; codecs="vorbis"'/><source data-bandwidth="210168" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="MP3" data-title="MP3" data-transcodekey="mp3" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/transcoded/e/ea/Beatles_norwegian_wood.ogg/Beatles_norwegian_wood.ogg.mp3" type="audio/mpeg"/><track data-dir="ltr" kind="subtitles" label="English ‪(en)‬" src="/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;title=File%3ABeatles_norwegian_wood.ogg&amp;lang=en&amp;trackformat=vtt" srclang="en" type="text/vtt"/></audio></div>
<div class="description">Sample of "Norwegian Wood" from <i>Rubber Soul</i> (1965). Harrison's use of a <a href="/wiki/Sitar" title="Sitar">sitar</a> on this song is representative of the Beatles' incorporation of unconventional instrumentation into rock music.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rubber_Soul_AllMusic_158-1"><a href="#cite_note-Rubber_Soul_AllMusic-158">[152]</a></sup></div></div></div></div>
<div class="side-box-abovebelow"><hr/><i class="selfreference">Problems playing this file? See <a href="/wiki/Help:Media" title="Help:Media">media help</a>.</i></div>
</div>
<p>While some of <i>Rubber Soul</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s songs were the product of Lennon and McCartney's collaborative songwriting,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpitz2005584–592_162-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpitz2005584–592-162">[156]</a></sup> the album also included distinct compositions from each,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiles1997268,_276,_278–279_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiles1997268,_276,_278–279-163">[157]</a></sup> though they continued to share official credit. "<a href="/wiki/In_My_Life" title="In My Life">In My Life</a>", of which each later claimed lead authorship, is considered a highlight of the entire Lennon–McCartney catalogue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpitz2005587_164-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpitz2005587-164">[158]</a></sup> Harrison called <i>Rubber Soul</i> his "favourite album",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Beatles2000194_160-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Beatles2000194-160">[154]</a></sup> and Starr referred to it as "the departure record".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpitz2005591_165-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpitz2005591-165">[159]</a></sup> McCartney has said, "We'd had our cute period, and now it was time to expand."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Beatles2000197_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Beatles2000197-166">[160]</a></sup> However, recording engineer <a href="/wiki/Norman_Smith_(record_producer)" title="Norman Smith (record producer)">Norman Smith</a> later stated that the studio sessions revealed signs of growing conflict within the group – "the clash between John and Paul was becoming obvious", he wrote, and "as far as Paul was concerned, George could do no right".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000b780_167-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000b780-167">[161]</a></sup> In 2003, <i><a href="/wiki/Rolling_Stone" title="Rolling Stone">Rolling Stone</a></i> ranked <i>Rubber Soul</i> fifth among "<a href="/wiki/Rolling_Stone%27s_500_Greatest_Albums_of_All_Time" title="Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Albums of All Time">The 500 Greatest Albums of All Time</a>",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RS_500_greatest_168-0"><a href="#cite_note-RS_500_greatest-168">[162]</a></sup> and AllMusic's <a href="/wiki/Richie_Unterberger" title="Richie Unterberger">Richie Unterberger</a> describes it as "one of the classic <a href="/wiki/Folk_rock" title="Folk rock">folk-rock</a> records".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AllMusic_biography_169-0"><a href="#cite_note-AllMusic_biography-169">[163]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Controversies.2C_Revolver_and_final_tour"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Controversies,_Revolver_and_final_tour">Controversies, <i>Revolver</i> and final tour</span></h4>
<p>Capitol Records, from December 1963 when it began issuing Beatles recordings for the US market, exercised complete control over format,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992350_86-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992350-86">[84]</a></sup> compiling distinct US albums from the band's recordings and issuing songs of their choosing as singles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007295–296_170-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007295–296-170">[164]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[nb 7]</a></sup> In June 1966, the Capitol LP <i><a href="/wiki/Yesterday_and_Today" title="Yesterday and Today">Yesterday and Today</a></i> caused an uproar with its cover, which portrayed the grinning Beatles dressed in butcher's overalls, accompanied by raw meat and mutilated plastic baby dolls. According to Beatles biographer <a href="/wiki/Bill_Harry" title="Bill Harry">Bill Harry</a>, it has been incorrectly suggested that this was meant as a satirical response to the way Capitol had "butchered" the US versions of the band's albums.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a1187_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a1187-173">[166]</a></sup> Thousands of copies of the LP had a new cover pasted over the original; an unpeeled "first-state" copy fetched $10,500 at a December 2005 auction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[167]</a></sup> In England, meanwhile, Harrison met sitar maestro <a href="/wiki/Ravi_Shankar" title="Ravi Shankar">Ravi Shankar</a>, who agreed to train him on the instrument.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELavezzoli2006176_175-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELavezzoli2006176-175">[168]</a></sup>
</p><p>During a tour of the Philippines the month after the <i>Yesterday and Today</i> furore, the Beatles unintentionally snubbed the nation's first lady, <a href="/wiki/Imelda_Marcos" title="Imelda Marcos">Imelda Marcos</a>, who had expected them to attend a breakfast reception at the <a href="/wiki/Malaca%C3%B1ang_Palace" title="Malacañang Palace">Presidential Palace</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpitz2005619_176-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpitz2005619-176">[169]</a></sup> When presented with the invitation, Epstein politely declined on the band members' behalf, as it had never been his policy to accept such official invitations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpitz2005620_177-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpitz2005620-177">[170]</a></sup> They soon found that the <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines_(1965%E2%80%931986)" title="History of the Philippines (1965–1986)">Marcos regime</a> was unaccustomed to taking no for an answer. The resulting riots endangered the group and they escaped the country with difficulty.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpitz2005623_178-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpitz2005623-178">[171]</a></sup> Immediately afterwards, the band members visited India for the first time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELavezzoli2006177_179-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELavezzoli2006177-179">[172]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1062260506">.mw-parser-output .quotebox{background-color:#F9F9F9;border:1px solid #aaa;box-sizing:border-box;padding:10px;font-size:88%;max-width:100%}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatleft{margin:.5em 1.4em .8em 0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatright{margin:.5em 0 .8em 1.4em}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.centered{overflow:hidden;position:relative;margin:.5em auto .8em auto}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatleft span,.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatright span{font-style:inherit}.mw-parser-output .quotebox>blockquote{margin:0;padding:0;border-left:0;font-family:inherit;font-size:inherit}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-title{background-color:#F9F9F9;text-align:center;font-size:110%;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote>:first-child{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote:last-child>:last-child{margin-bottom:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote.quoted:before{font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;font-weight:bold;font-size:large;color:gray;content:" “ ";vertical-align:-45%;line-height:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote.quoted:after{font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;font-weight:bold;font-size:large;color:gray;content:" ” ";line-height:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .left-aligned{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .right-aligned{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .center-aligned{text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .quote-title,.mw-parser-output .quotebox .quotebox-quote{display:block}.mw-parser-output .quotebox cite{display:block;font-style:normal}@media screen and (max-width:640px){.mw-parser-output .quotebox{width:100%!important;margin:0 0 .8em!important;float:none!important}}</style><div class="quotebox pullquote floatright" style="width:25em; ;">
<blockquote class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style="">
<p>We're <a href="/wiki/More_popular_than_Jesus" title="More popular than Jesus">more popular than Jesus</a> now; I don't know which will go first – rock 'n' roll or Christianity.
</p>
</blockquote>
<p><cite class="left-aligned" style="">– John Lennon, 1966<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007309_180-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007309-180">[173]</a></sup></cite>
</p>
</div>
<p>Almost as soon as they returned home, the Beatles faced a fierce backlash from US religious and social conservatives (as well as the <a href="/wiki/Ku_Klux_Klan" title="Ku Klux Klan">Ku Klux Klan</a>) over a comment Lennon had made in a March interview with British reporter <a href="/wiki/Maureen_Cleave" title="Maureen Cleave">Maureen Cleave</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992212–213_181-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992212–213-181">[174]</a></sup> "Christianity will go", Lennon had said. "It will vanish and shrink. I needn't argue about that; I'm right and I will be proved right ... <a href="/wiki/Jesus" title="Jesus">Jesus</a> was alright but his <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Disciples_(Christianity)" title="Disciples (Christianity)">disciples</a> were thick and ordinary. It's them twisting it that ruins it for me."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007307–309_182-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007307–309-182">[175]</a></sup> His comments went virtually unnoticed in England, but when US teenage fan magazine <i>Datebook</i> printed them five months later, it sparked a controversy with Christians in America's conservative <a href="/wiki/Bible_Belt" title="Bible Belt">Bible Belt</a> region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992212–213_181-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992212–213-181">[174]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Vatican</a> issued a protest, and bans on Beatles' records were imposed by Spanish and Dutch stations and South Africa's <a href="/wiki/South_African_Broadcasting_Corporation" title="South African Broadcasting Corporation">national broadcasting service</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENorman2008449_183-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorman2008449-183">[176]</a></sup> Epstein accused <i>Datebook</i> of having taken Lennon's words out of context. At a press conference, Lennon pointed out, "If I'd said television was more popular than Jesus, I might have got away with it."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007346_184-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007346-184">[177]</a></sup> He claimed that he was referring to how other people viewed their success, but at the prompting of reporters, he concluded: "If you want me to apologise, if that will make you happy, then okay, I'm sorry."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007346_184-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007346-184">[177]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1097025294" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096940132" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="side-box side-box-left listen noprint listen-left">
<div class="side-box-flex">
<div class="side-box-image"><div class="center"><div class="floatnone"><img alt="" data-file-height="160" data-file-width="160" decoding="async" height="50" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/50px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/75px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/100px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png 2x" width="50"/></div></div></div>
<div class="side-box-text plainlist"><div class="haudio">
<div class="listen-file-header"><a href="/wiki/File:Beatles_eleanor_rigby.ogg" title="File:Beatles eleanor rigby.ogg">"Eleanor Rigby"</a></div>
<div><audio controls="" data-durationhint="13" data-mwprovider="local" data-mwtitle="Beatles_eleanor_rigby.ogg" id="mwe_player_2" preload="none" style="width:232px;" width="232"><source data-bandwidth="40608" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" data-title="Original Ogg file (41 kbps)" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/f/f9/Beatles_eleanor_rigby.ogg" type='audio/ogg; codecs="vorbis"'/><source data-bandwidth="164584" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="MP3" data-title="MP3" data-transcodekey="mp3" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/transcoded/f/f9/Beatles_eleanor_rigby.ogg/Beatles_eleanor_rigby.ogg.mp3" type="audio/mpeg"/><track data-dir="ltr" kind="subtitles" label="English ‪(en)‬" src="/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;title=File%3ABeatles_eleanor_rigby.ogg&amp;lang=en&amp;trackformat=vtt" srclang="en" type="text/vtt"/></audio></div>
<div class="description">Sample of "<a href="/wiki/Eleanor_Rigby" title="Eleanor Rigby">Eleanor Rigby</a>" from <i>Revolver</i> (1966). The album involves innovative compositional approaches, arrangements and recording techniques. This song, primarily written by McCartney, prominently features classical strings in a novel fusion of musical styles.</div></div></div></div>
<div class="side-box-abovebelow"><hr/><i class="selfreference">Problems playing this file? See <a href="/wiki/Help:Media" title="Help:Media">media help</a>.</i></div>
</div>
<p>Released in August 1966, a week before the Beatles' final tour, <i><a href="/wiki/Revolver_(Beatles_album)" title="Revolver (Beatles album)">Revolver</a></i> marked another artistic step forward for the group.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007348_185-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007348-185">[178]</a></sup> The album featured sophisticated songwriting, studio experimentation, and a greatly expanded repertoire of musical styles, ranging from innovative classical string arrangements to <a href="/wiki/Psychedelic_music" title="Psychedelic music">psychedelia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007348_185-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007348-185">[178]</a></sup> Abandoning the customary group photograph, its <a href="/wiki/Aubrey_Beardsley" title="Aubrey Beardsley">Aubrey Beardsley</a>-inspired cover – designed by <a href="/wiki/Klaus_Voormann" title="Klaus Voormann">Klaus Voormann</a>, a friend of the band since their Hamburg days – was a monochrome collage and line drawing caricature of the group.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007348_185-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007348-185">[178]</a></sup> The album was preceded by the single "<a href="/wiki/Paperback_Writer" title="Paperback Writer">Paperback Writer</a>", backed by "<a href="/wiki/Rain_(Beatles_song)" title="Rain (Beatles song)">Rain</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992350–351_186-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992350–351-186">[179]</a></sup> Short promotional films were made for both songs; described by cultural historian Saul Austerlitz as "among the first true music videos",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAusterlitz200718_187-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAusterlitz200718-187">[180]</a></sup> they aired on <i>The Ed Sullivan Show</i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Top_of_the_Pops" title="Top of the Pops">Top of the Pops</a></i> in June.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992221–222_188-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992221–222-188">[181]</a></sup>
</p><p>Among the experimental songs on <i>Revolver</i> was "<a href="/wiki/Tomorrow_Never_Knows" title="Tomorrow Never Knows">Tomorrow Never Knows</a>", the lyrics for which Lennon drew from <a href="/wiki/Timothy_Leary" title="Timothy Leary">Timothy Leary</a>'s <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Psychedelic_Experience:_A_Manual_Based_on_the_Tibetan_Book_of_the_Dead" title="The Psychedelic Experience: A Manual Based on the Tibetan Book of the Dead">The Psychedelic Experience: A Manual Based on the Tibetan Book of the Dead</a></i>. Its creation involved eight tape decks distributed about the EMI building, each staffed by an engineer or band member, who randomly varied the movement of a <a href="/wiki/Tape_loop" title="Tape loop">tape loop</a> while Martin created a composite recording by sampling the incoming data.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007364–366_189-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007364–366-189">[182]</a></sup> McCartney's "<a href="/wiki/Eleanor_Rigby" title="Eleanor Rigby">Eleanor Rigby</a>" made prominent use of a <a href="/wiki/Octet_(music)" title="Octet (music)">string octet</a>; Gould describes it as "a true hybrid, conforming to no recognisable style or genre of song".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007350,_402_190-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007350,_402-190">[183]</a></sup> Harrison's emergence as a songwriter was reflected in three of his compositions appearing on the record.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchaffner197863_191-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchaffner197863-191">[184]</a></sup> Among these, "<a href="/wiki/Taxman" title="Taxman">Taxman</a>", which opened the album, marked the first example of the Beatles making a political statement through their music.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETurner2016162_192-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETurner2016162-192">[185]</a></sup> In 2003, <i>Rolling Stone</i> ranked <i>Revolver</i> as the third greatest album of all time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RS_500_greatest_168-1"><a href="#cite_note-RS_500_greatest-168">[162]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Candlestick_Postcard_-_01.JPG"><img alt="San Francisco's Candlestick Park in the 1960s" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="530" data-file-width="824" decoding="async" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Candlestick_Postcard_-_01.JPG/260px-Candlestick_Postcard_-_01.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Candlestick_Postcard_-_01.JPG/390px-Candlestick_Postcard_-_01.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Candlestick_Postcard_-_01.JPG/520px-Candlestick_Postcard_-_01.JPG 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Candlestick_Postcard_-_01.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>San Francisco's <a href="/wiki/Candlestick_Park" title="Candlestick Park">Candlestick Park</a> (pictured in the early 1960s) was the venue for the Beatles' final concert before a paying audience.</div></div></div>
<p>As preparations were made for a tour of the US, the Beatles knew that their music would hardly be heard. Having originally used <a href="/wiki/Vox_AC30" title="Vox AC30">Vox AC30</a> amplifiers, they later acquired more powerful 100-watt amplifiers, specially designed for them by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vox_(musical_equipment)" title="Vox (musical equipment)">Vox</a>, as they moved into larger venues in 1964; however, these were still inadequate. Struggling to compete with the volume of sound generated by screaming fans, the band had grown increasingly bored with the routine of performing live.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a1093_193-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a1093-193">[186]</a></sup> Recognising that their shows were no longer about the music, they decided to make the August tour their last.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992210,_230_194-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992210,_230-194">[187]</a></sup>
</p><p>The band performed none of their new songs on the tour.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992361–365_195-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992361–365-195">[188]</a></sup> In Chris Ingham's description, they were very much "studio creations ... and there was no way a four-piece rock 'n' roll group could do them justice, particularly through the desensitising wall of the fans' screams. 'Live Beatles' and 'Studio Beatles' had become entirely different beasts."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEIngham200644_196-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIngham200644-196">[189]</a></sup> The band's concert at San Francisco's <a href="/wiki/Candlestick_Park" title="Candlestick Park">Candlestick Park</a> on 29 August was their last commercial concert.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiles1997293–295_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiles1997293–295-197">[190]</a></sup> It marked the end of four years dominated by almost non-stop touring that included over 1,400 concert appearances internationally.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould20075–6,_249,_281,_347_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould20075–6,_249,_281,_347-198">[191]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="1966.E2.80.931970:_Studio_years"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1966–1970:_Studio_years">1966–1970: Studio years</span></h3>
<h4><span id="Sgt._Pepper.27s_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Sgt._Pepper's_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band"><i>Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band</i></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sgt._Pepper%27s_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band" title="Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band">Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sgt._Pepper%27s_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band.jpg"><img alt="The album artwork of the Beatles' 1967 album Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/5/50/Sgt._Pepper%27s_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band.jpg/220px-Sgt._Pepper%27s_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/5/50/Sgt._Pepper%27s_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band.jpg 1.5x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sgt._Pepper%27s_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Front cover of <i><a href="/wiki/Sgt._Pepper%27s_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band" title="Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band">Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band</a></i>, "the most famous cover of any music album, and one of the most imitated images in the world"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a970_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a970-199">[192]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Freed from the burden of touring, the Beatles embraced an increasingly experimental approach as they recorded <i><a href="/wiki/Sgt._Pepper%27s_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band" title="Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band">Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band</a></i>, beginning in late November 1966.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992232_200-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992232-200">[193]</a></sup> According to engineer <a href="/wiki/Geoff_Emerick" title="Geoff Emerick">Geoff Emerick</a>, the album's recording took over 700 hours.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEmerickMassey2006190_201-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEmerickMassey2006190-201">[194]</a></sup> He recalled the band's insistence "that everything on <i>Sgt. Pepper</i> had to be different. We had microphones right down in the bells of brass instruments and headphones turned into microphones attached to violins. We used giant primitive oscillators to vary the speed of instruments and vocals and we had tapes chopped to pieces and stuck together upside down and the wrong way around."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007387–388_202-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007387–388-202">[195]</a></sup> Parts of "<a href="/wiki/A_Day_in_the_Life" title="A Day in the Life">A Day in the Life</a>" featured a 40-piece orchestra.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007387–388_202-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007387–388-202">[195]</a></sup> The sessions initially yielded the non-album <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Double_A-side" title="Double A-side">double A-side</a> single "<a href="/wiki/Strawberry_Fields_Forever" title="Strawberry Fields Forever">Strawberry Fields Forever</a>"/"<a href="/wiki/Penny_Lane" title="Penny Lane">Penny Lane</a>" in February 1967;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMacDonald2005221_203-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMacDonald2005221-203">[196]</a></sup> the <i>Sgt. Pepper</i> LP followed with a rush-release in May.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEverett1999123_204-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEverett1999123-204">[197]</a></sup> The musical complexity of the records, created using relatively primitive <a href="/wiki/Multitrack_recording" title="Multitrack recording">four-track</a> recording technology, astounded contemporary artists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a970_199-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a970-199">[192]</a></sup> Among music critics, acclaim for the album was virtually universal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007420–425_205-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007420–425-205">[198]</a></sup> Gould writes:
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r996844942">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>The overwhelming consensus is that the Beatles had created a popular masterpiece: a rich, sustained, and overflowing work of collaborative genius whose bold ambition and startling originality dramatically enlarged the possibilities and raised the expectations of what the experience of listening to popular music on record could be. On the basis of this perception, <i>Sgt. Pepper</i> became the catalyst for an explosion of mass enthusiasm for album-formatted rock that would revolutionise both the aesthetics and the economics of the record business in ways that far outstripped the earlier pop explosions triggered by the Elvis phenomenon of 1956 and the Beatlemania phenomenon of 1963.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007418_206-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007418-206">[199]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>In the wake of <i>Sgt. Pepper</i>, the underground and mainstream press widely publicised the Beatles as leaders of youth culture, as well as "lifestyle revolutionaries".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrontani2007157_3-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrontani2007157-3">[3]</a></sup> The album was the first major pop/rock LP to include its complete lyrics, which appeared on the back cover.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992236_207-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992236-207">[200]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEInglis200896_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInglis200896-208">[201]</a></sup> Those lyrics were the subject of critical analysis; for instance, in late 1967 the album was the subject of a scholarly inquiry by American literary critic and professor of English <a href="/wiki/Richard_Poirier" title="Richard Poirier">Richard Poirier</a>, who observed that his students were "listening to the group's music with a degree of engagement that he, as a teacher of literature, could only envy".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007423–425_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007423–425-209">[202]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[nb 8]</a></sup> The elaborate cover also attracted considerable interest and study.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007394–395_211-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007394–395-211">[203]</a></sup> A collage designed by <a href="/wiki/Pop_art" title="Pop art">pop artists</a> <a href="/wiki/Peter_Blake_(artist)" title="Peter Blake (artist)">Peter Blake</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jann_Haworth" title="Jann Haworth">Jann Haworth</a>, it depicted the group as the fictional band referred to in the album's <a href="/wiki/Sgt._Pepper%27s_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band_(song)" title="Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band (song)">title track</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMacDonald2005312_212-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMacDonald2005312-212">[204]</a></sup> standing in front of <a href="/wiki/List_of_images_on_the_cover_of_Sgt._Pepper%27s_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band" title="List of images on the cover of Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band">a crowd of famous people</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Beatles2000248_213-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Beatles2000248-213">[205]</a></sup> The heavy moustaches worn by the group reflected the growing influence of <a href="/wiki/Hippie" title="Hippie">hippie</a> style,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Beatles2000236_214-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Beatles2000236-214">[206]</a></sup> while cultural historian Jonathan Harris describes their "brightly coloured parodies of military uniforms" as a knowingly "anti-authoritarian and anti-establishment" display.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarris200512–13_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarris200512–13-215">[207]</a></sup>
</p><p><i>Sgt. Pepper</i> topped the UK charts for 23 consecutive weeks, with a further four weeks at number one in the period through to February 1968.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[208]</a></sup> With 2.5 million copies sold within three months of its release,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrontani2007147_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrontani2007147-217">[209]</a></sup> <i>Sgt. Pepper</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s initial commercial success exceeded that of all previous Beatles albums.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpitz2005697_218-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpitz2005697-218">[210]</a></sup> It sustained its immense popularity into the 21st century while breaking numerous sales records.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[211]</a></sup> In 2003, <i>Rolling Stone</i> ranked <i>Sgt. Pepper</i> at number one on its list of the greatest albums of all time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RS_500_greatest_168-2"><a href="#cite_note-RS_500_greatest-168">[162]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Magical_Mystery_Tour_and_Yellow_Submarine"><i>Magical Mystery Tour</i> and <i>Yellow Submarine</i></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Magical_Mystery_Tour_(film)" title="Magical Mystery Tour (film)">Magical Mystery Tour (film)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yellow_Submarine_(film)" title="Yellow Submarine (film)">Yellow Submarine (film)</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Beatles_-_All_You_Need_Is_Love_%26_Baby,_You%27re_a_Rich_Man,_1967_(cropped).png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="653" data-file-width="498" decoding="async" height="288" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/The_Beatles_-_All_You_Need_Is_Love_%26_Baby%2C_You%27re_a_Rich_Man%2C_1967_%28cropped%29.png/220px-The_Beatles_-_All_You_Need_Is_Love_%26_Baby%2C_You%27re_a_Rich_Man%2C_1967_%28cropped%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/The_Beatles_-_All_You_Need_Is_Love_%26_Baby%2C_You%27re_a_Rich_Man%2C_1967_%28cropped%29.png/330px-The_Beatles_-_All_You_Need_Is_Love_%26_Baby%2C_You%27re_a_Rich_Man%2C_1967_%28cropped%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/The_Beatles_-_All_You_Need_Is_Love_%26_Baby%2C_You%27re_a_Rich_Man%2C_1967_%28cropped%29.png/440px-The_Beatles_-_All_You_Need_Is_Love_%26_Baby%2C_You%27re_a_Rich_Man%2C_1967_%28cropped%29.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Beatles_-_All_You_Need_Is_Love_%26_Baby,_You%27re_a_Rich_Man,_1967_(cropped).png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Beatles in 1967; clockwise from left: Lennon, McCartney, Harrison and Starr</div></div></div>
<p>Two Beatles film projects were conceived within weeks of completing <i>Sgt. Pepper</i>: <i><a href="/wiki/Magical_Mystery_Tour_(film)" title="Magical Mystery Tour (film)">Magical Mystery Tour</a></i>, a one-hour television film, and <i><a href="/wiki/Yellow_Submarine_(film)" title="Yellow Submarine (film)">Yellow Submarine</a></i>, an animated feature-length film produced by <a href="/wiki/United_Artists" title="United Artists">United Artists</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn198841,_110–111,_122_220-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn198841,_110–111,_122-220">[212]</a></sup> The group began recording music for the former in late April 1967, but the project then lay dormant as they focused on recording songs for the latter.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiles2001276–77_221-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiles2001276–77-221">[213]</a></sup> On 25 June, the Beatles performed their forthcoming single "<a href="/wiki/All_You_Need_Is_Love" title="All You Need Is Love">All You Need Is Love</a>" to an estimated 350 million viewers on <i><a href="/wiki/Our_World_(1967_TV_program)" title="Our World (1967 TV program)">Our World</a></i>, the first live global television link.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992237,_259–260_222-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992237,_259–260-222">[214]</a></sup> Released a week later, during the <a href="/wiki/Summer_of_Love" title="Summer of Love">Summer of Love</a>, the song was adopted as a <a href="/wiki/Flower_power" title="Flower power">flower power</a> anthem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007428–429_223-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007428–429-223">[215]</a></sup> The Beatles' use of psychedelic drugs was at its height during that summer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEverett1999129_224-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEverett1999129-224">[216]</a></sup> In July and August, the group pursued interests related to similar utopian-based ideology, including a week-long investigation into the possibility of starting an island-based <a href="/wiki/Intentional_community" title="Intentional community">commune</a> off the coast of Greece.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWomack2007197_225-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWomack2007197-225">[217]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 24 August, the group were introduced to <a href="/wiki/Maharishi_Mahesh_Yogi" title="Maharishi Mahesh Yogi">Maharishi Mahesh Yogi</a> in London. The next day, they travelled to <a href="/wiki/Bangor,_Gwynedd" title="Bangor, Gwynedd">Bangor</a> for his <a href="/wiki/Transcendental_Meditation" title="Transcendental Meditation">Transcendental Meditation</a> retreat. On 27 August, their manager's assistant, Peter Brown, phoned to inform them that Epstein had died.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpitz2005709,_713–719_226-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpitz2005709,_713–719-226">[218]</a></sup> The coroner ruled the death an accidental <a href="/wiki/Bromoureide" title="Bromoureide">carbitol</a> overdose, although it was widely rumoured to be a suicide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrownGaines2002249_227-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrownGaines2002249-227">[219]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[nb 9]</a></sup> His death left the group disoriented and fearful about the future.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Beatles2000268_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Beatles2000268-230">[221]</a></sup> Lennon recalled: "We collapsed. I knew that we were in trouble then. I didn't really have any misconceptions about our ability to do anything other than play music, and I was scared. I thought, 'We've fuckin' had it now.<span style="padding-right:.15em;">'</span>"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENorman2008508_231-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorman2008508-231">[222]</a></sup> Harrison's then-wife <a href="/wiki/Pattie_Boyd" title="Pattie Boyd">Pattie Boyd</a> remembered that "Paul and George were in complete shock. I don't think it could have been worse if they had heard that their own fathers had dropped dead."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBoyd2008106–107_232-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBoyd2008106–107-232">[223]</a></sup> During a band meeting in September, McCartney recommended that the band proceed with <i>Magical Mystery Tour</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiles2001276–77_221-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiles2001276–77-221">[213]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Magical_Mystery_Tour" title="Magical Mystery Tour"><i>Magical Mystery Tour</i> soundtrack</a> was released in the UK as a six-track double <a href="/wiki/Extended_play" title="Extended play">extended play</a> (EP) in early December 1967.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992350_86-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992350-86">[84]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007452_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007452-233">[224]</a></sup> It was the first example of a double EP in the UK.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENeaverson199753_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENeaverson199753-234">[225]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarkin2006488_235-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarkin2006488-235">[226]</a></sup> The record carried on the psychedelic vein of <i>Sgt. Pepper</i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[227]</a></sup> however, in line with the band's wishes, the packaging reinforced the idea that the release was a film soundtrack rather than a follow-up to <i>Sgt. Pepper</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007452_233-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007452-233">[224]</a></sup> In the US, the soundtrack appeared as an identically titled LP that also included five tracks from the band's recent singles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992351_109-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992351-109">[106]</a></sup> In its first three weeks, the album set a record for the highest initial sales of any Capitol LP, and it is the only Capitol compilation later to be adopted in the band's official canon of studio albums.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a699_237-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a699-237">[228]</a></sup>
</p><p><i>Magical Mystery Tour</i> first aired on <a href="/wiki/Boxing_Day" title="Boxing Day">Boxing Day</a> to an audience of approximately 15 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchaffner197890_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchaffner197890-238">[229]</a></sup> Largely directed by McCartney, the film was the band's first critical failure in the UK.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiles1997368–69_239-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiles1997368–69-239">[230]</a></sup> It was dismissed as "blatant rubbish" by the <i><a href="/wiki/Daily_Express" title="Daily Express">Daily Express</a></i>; the <i><a href="/wiki/Daily_Mail" title="Daily Mail">Daily Mail</a></i> called it "a colossal conceit"; and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i> labelled the film "a kind of fantasy morality play about the grossness and warmth and stupidity of the audience".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007455–456_240-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007455–456-240">[231]</a></sup> Gould describes it as "a great deal of raw footage showing a group of people getting on, getting off, and riding on a bus".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007455–456_240-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007455–456-240">[231]</a></sup> Although the viewership figures were respectable, its slating in the press led US television networks to lose interest in broadcasting the film.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a703_241-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a703-241">[232]</a></sup>
</p><p>The group were less involved with <i>Yellow Submarine</i>, which featured the band appearing as themselves for only a short live-action segment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992276_242-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992276-242">[233]</a></sup> Premiering in July 1968, the film featured cartoon versions of the band members and a soundtrack with eleven of their songs, including four unreleased studio recordings that made their debut in the film.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007485_243-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007485-243">[234]</a></sup> Critics praised the film for its music, humour and innovative visual style.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007487–88,_505–506_244-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007487–88,_505–506-244">[235]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Yellow_Submarine_(album)" title="Yellow Submarine (album)">soundtrack LP</a> was issued seven months later; it contained those four new songs, the title track (already issued on <i>Revolver</i>), "All You Need Is Love" (already issued as a single and on the US <i>Magical Mystery Tour</i> LP) and seven instrumental pieces composed by Martin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992304,_350_245-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992304,_350-245">[236]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="India_retreat.2C_Apple_Corps_and_the_White_Album"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="India_retreat,_Apple_Corps_and_the_White_Album">India retreat, Apple Corps and the White Album</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Beatles_in_India" title="Beatles in India">Beatles in India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apple_Corps" title="Apple Corps">Apple Corps</a>, and <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles_(album)" title="The Beatles (album)">The Beatles (album)</a></div>
<p>In February 1968, the Beatles travelled to Maharishi Mahesh Yogi's <a href="/wiki/Ashram" title="Ashram">ashram</a> in <a href="/wiki/Rishikesh" title="Rishikesh">Rishikesh</a>, India, to take part in a three-month meditation "Guide Course". Their <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles_in_India" title="The Beatles in India">time in India</a> marked one of the band's most prolific periods, yielding numerous songs, including a majority of those on their next album.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a108–109_246-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a108–109-246">[237]</a></sup> However, Starr left after only ten days, unable to stomach the food, and McCartney eventually grew bored and departed a month later.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007463–468_247-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007463–468-247">[238]</a></sup> For Lennon and Harrison, creativity turned to question when an electronics technician known as <a href="/wiki/Magic_Alex" title="Magic Alex">Magic Alex</a> suggested that the Maharishi was attempting to manipulate them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a705–706_248-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a705–706-248">[239]</a></sup> When he alleged that the Maharishi had made sexual advances to women attendees, a persuaded Lennon left abruptly just two months into the course, bringing an unconvinced Harrison and the remainder of the group's entourage with him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007463–468_247-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007463–468-247">[238]</a></sup> In anger, Lennon wrote a scathing song titled "Maharishi", renamed "<a href="/wiki/Sexy_Sadie" title="Sexy Sadie">Sexy Sadie</a>" to avoid potential legal issues. McCartney said, "We made a mistake. We thought there was more to him than there was."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a705–706_248-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a705–706-248">[239]</a></sup>
</p><p>In May, Lennon and McCartney travelled to New York for the public unveiling of the Beatles' new business venture, <a href="/wiki/Apple_Corps" title="Apple Corps">Apple Corps</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992282_249-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992282-249">[240]</a></sup> It was initially formed several months earlier as part of a plan to create a tax-effective business structure, but the band then desired to extend the corporation to other pursuits, including record distribution, peace activism, and education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoggett201120,_26_250-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoggett201120,_26-250">[241]</a></sup> McCartney described Apple as "rather like a Western communism".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoggett201126_251-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoggett201126-251">[242]</a></sup> The enterprise drained the group financially with a series of unsuccessful projects<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMacDonald2005280–281_252-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMacDonald2005280–281-252">[243]</a></sup> handled largely by members of the Beatles' entourage, who were given their jobs regardless of talent and experience.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoggett201122_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoggett201122-253">[244]</a></sup> Among its numerous subsidiaries were <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Apple_Electronics" title="Apple Electronics">Apple Electronics</a>, established to foster technological innovations with Magic Alex at the head, and Apple Retailing, which opened the short-lived <a href="/wiki/Apple_Boutique" title="Apple Boutique">Apple Boutique</a> in London.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoggett201120,_22,_25,_35_254-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoggett201120,_22,_25,_35-254">[245]</a></sup> Harrison later said, "Basically, it was chaos ... John and Paul got carried away with the idea and blew millions, and Ringo and I just had to go along with it."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoggett201126_251-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoggett201126-251">[242]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:TheBeatles68LP.jpg"><img alt="The album artwork of the Beatles' self-titled 1968 album, also known as &quot;the White Album&quot;" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="720" data-file-width="720" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/TheBeatles68LP.jpg/220px-TheBeatles68LP.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/TheBeatles68LP.jpg/330px-TheBeatles68LP.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/TheBeatles68LP.jpg/440px-TheBeatles68LP.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:TheBeatles68LP.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>The Beatles</i>, known as "the White Album" for its minimalist cover, conceived by pop artist <a href="/wiki/Richard_Hamilton_(artist)" title="Richard Hamilton (artist)">Richard Hamilton</a> "in direct contrast to <i>Sgt. Pepper</i>", while also suggesting a "clean slate"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007510–511_255-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007510–511-255">[246]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>From late May to mid-October 1968, the group recorded what became <i><a href="/wiki/The_Beatles_(album)" title="The Beatles (album)">The Beatles</a></i>, a double LP commonly known as "the White Album" for its virtually featureless cover.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007510_256-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007510-256">[247]</a></sup> During this time, relations between the members grew openly divisive.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMacDonald2005310_257-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMacDonald2005310-257">[248]</a></sup> Starr quit for two weeks, leaving his bandmates to record "<a href="/wiki/Back_in_the_U.S.S.R." title="Back in the U.S.S.R.">Back in the U.S.S.R.</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/Dear_Prudence" title="Dear Prudence">Dear Prudence</a>" as a trio, with McCartney filling in on drums.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWinn2009205–207_258-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWinn2009205–207-258">[249]</a></sup> Lennon had lost interest in collaborating with McCartney,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007513,_516_259-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007513,_516-259">[250]</a></sup> whose contribution "<a href="/wiki/Ob-La-Di,_Ob-La-Da" title="Ob-La-Di, Ob-La-Da">Ob-La-Di, Ob-La-Da</a>" he scorned as "granny music shit".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEmerickMassey2006246_260-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEmerickMassey2006246-260">[251]</a></sup> Tensions were further aggravated by Lennon's romantic preoccupation with <a href="/wiki/Avant-garde" title="Avant-garde">avant-garde</a> artist <a href="/wiki/Yoko_Ono" title="Yoko Ono">Yoko Ono</a>, whom he insisted on bringing to the sessions despite the group's well-established understanding that girlfriends were not allowed in the studio.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000b103_261-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000b103-261">[252]</a></sup> McCartney has recalled that the album "wasn't a pleasant one to make".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Beatles2000310_262-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Beatles2000310-262">[253]</a></sup> He and Lennon identified the sessions as the start of the band's break-up.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThe_Beatles2000237_263-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Beatles2000237-263">[254]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000b102_264-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000b102-264">[255]</a></sup>
</p><p>With the record, the band executed a wider range of musical styles<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiles2001315_265-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiles2001315-265">[256]</a></sup> and broke with their recent tradition of incorporating several musical styles in one song by keeping each piece of music consistently faithful to a select genre.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[257]</a></sup> During the sessions, the group upgraded to an eight-track tape console, which made it easier for them to layer tracks piecemeal, while the members often recorded independently of each other, affording the album a reputation as a collection of solo recordings rather than a unified group effort.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1988137,_146,_150,_152_267-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1988137,_146,_150,_152-267">[258]</a></sup> Describing the double album, Lennon later said: "Every track is an individual track; there isn't any Beatle music on it. [It's] John and the band, Paul and the band, George and the band."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007509_268-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007509-268">[259]</a></sup> The sessions also produced the Beatles' longest song yet, "<a href="/wiki/Hey_Jude" title="Hey Jude">Hey Jude</a>", released in August as a non-album single with "<a href="/wiki/Revolution_(Beatles_song)" title="Revolution (Beatles song)">Revolution</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1988152_269-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1988152-269">[260]</a></sup>
</p><p>Issued in November, the White Album was the band's first <a href="/wiki/Apple_Records" title="Apple Records">Apple Records</a> album release, although EMI continued to own their recordings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992278_270-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992278-270">[261]</a></sup> The record attracted more than 2 million advance orders, selling nearly 4 million copies in the US in little over a month, and its tracks dominated the playlists of American radio stations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007528_271-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007528-271">[262]</a></sup> Its lyric content was the focus of much analysis by the counterculture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMacDonald2005311–313_272-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMacDonald2005311–313-272">[263]</a></sup> Despite its popularity, reviewers were largely confused by the album's content, and it failed to inspire the level of critical writing that <i>Sgt. Pepper</i> had.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007528_271-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007528-271">[262]</a></sup> General critical opinion eventually turned in favour of the White Album, and in 2003, <i>Rolling Stone</i> ranked it as the tenth greatest album of all time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RS_500_greatest_168-3"><a href="#cite_note-RS_500_greatest-168">[162]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Abbey_Road.2C_Let_It_Be_and_separation"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Abbey_Road,_Let_It_Be_and_separation"><i>Abbey Road</i>, <i>Let It Be</i> and separation</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Break-up_of_the_Beatles" title="Break-up of the Beatles">Break-up of the Beatles</a></div>
<p>Although <i><a href="/wiki/Let_It_Be_(Beatles_album)" title="Let It Be (Beatles album)">Let It Be</a></i> was the Beatles' final album release, it was largely recorded before <i><a href="/wiki/Abbey_Road" title="Abbey Road">Abbey Road</a></i>. The project's impetus came from an idea Martin attributes to McCartney, who suggested they "record an album of new material and rehearse it, then perform it before a live audience for the very first time – on record and on film".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000b539_273-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000b539-273">[264]</a></sup> Originally intended for a one-hour television programme to be called <i>Beatles at Work</i>, in the event much of the album's content came from studio work beginning in January 1969, many hours of which were captured on film by director <a href="/wiki/Michael_Lindsay-Hogg" title="Michael Lindsay-Hogg">Michael Lindsay-Hogg</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000b539_273-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000b539-273">[264]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992306–307_274-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992306–307-274">[265]</a></sup> Martin said that the project was "not at all a happy recording experience. It was a time when relations between the Beatles were at their lowest ebb."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000b539_273-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000b539-273">[264]</a></sup> Lennon described the largely impromptu sessions as "hell ... the most miserable ... on Earth", and Harrison, "the low of all-time".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992310_275-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992310-275">[266]</a></sup> Irritated by McCartney and Lennon, Harrison walked out for five days. Upon returning, he threatened to leave the band unless they "abandon[ed] all talk of live performance" and instead focused on finishing a new album, initially titled <i>Get Back</i>, using songs recorded for the TV special.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992307_276-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992307-276">[267]</a></sup> He also demanded they cease work at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Twickenham_Film_Studios" title="Twickenham Film Studios">Twickenham Film Studios</a>, where the sessions had begun, and relocate to the newly finished <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Apple_Studios_(recording_studio)" title="Apple Studios (recording studio)">Apple Studio</a>. His bandmates agreed, and it was decided to salvage the footage shot for the TV production for use in a feature film.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992306–307,_309_277-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992306–307,_309-277">[268]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Billy_Preston_perforning_in_1971.jpg"><img alt="American musician Billy Preston in 1971" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2314" data-file-width="3442" decoding="async" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Billy_Preston_perforning_in_1971.jpg/220px-Billy_Preston_perforning_in_1971.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Billy_Preston_perforning_in_1971.jpg/330px-Billy_Preston_perforning_in_1971.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Billy_Preston_perforning_in_1971.jpg/440px-Billy_Preston_perforning_in_1971.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Billy_Preston_perforning_in_1971.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The American soul musician <a href="/wiki/Billy_Preston" title="Billy Preston">Billy Preston</a> (pictured in 1971) was, for a short time, considered a <a href="/wiki/Fifth_Beatle" title="Fifth Beatle">fifth Beatle</a> during the <i>Get Back</i> sessions.</div></div></div>
<p>To alleviate tensions within the band and improve the quality of their live sound, Harrison invited keyboardist <a href="/wiki/Billy_Preston" title="Billy Preston">Billy Preston</a> to participate in the last nine days of sessions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992309–314_278-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992309–314-278">[269]</a></sup> Preston received label billing on the "<a href="/wiki/Get_Back" title="Get Back">Get Back</a>" single – the only musician ever to receive that acknowledgment on an official Beatles release.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a451,_660_279-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a451,_660-279">[270]</a></sup> After the rehearsals, the band could not agree on a location to film a concert, rejecting several ideas, including a boat at sea, a lunatic asylum, the Tunisian desert, and the <a href="/wiki/Colosseum" title="Colosseum">Colosseum</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000b539_273-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000b539-273">[264]</a></sup> Ultimately, what would be their <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles%27_rooftop_concert" title="The Beatles' rooftop concert">final live performance</a> was filmed on the rooftop of the Apple Corps building at 3 <a href="/wiki/Savile_Row" title="Savile Row">Savile Row</a>, London, on 30 January 1969.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992307–308,_312_280-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992307–308,_312-280">[271]</a></sup> Five weeks later, engineer <a href="/wiki/Glyn_Johns" title="Glyn Johns">Glyn Johns</a>, whom Lewisohn describes as <i>Get Back</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s "uncredited producer", began work assembling an album, given "free rein" as the band "all but washed their hands of the entire project".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992309,_316–323_281-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992309,_316–323-281">[272]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:3_Savile_Row.jpg"><img alt="A terrace house with four floors and an attic. It is red brick, with a slate roof, and the ground floor rendered in imitation of stone and painted white. Each upper floor has four sash windows, divided into small panes. The door, with a canopy over it, occupies the place of the second window from the left on the ground floor." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3872" data-file-width="2146" decoding="async" height="307" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/3_Savile_Row.jpg/170px-3_Savile_Row.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/3_Savile_Row.jpg/255px-3_Savile_Row.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/3_Savile_Row.jpg/340px-3_Savile_Row.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:3_Savile_Row.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Apple Corps building at 3 Savile Row, site of the <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles%27_rooftop_concert" title="The Beatles' rooftop concert"><i>Let It Be</i> rooftop concert</a></div></div></div>
<p>New strains developed between the band members regarding the appointment of a financial adviser, the need for which had become evident without Epstein to manage business affairs. Lennon, Harrison and Starr favoured <a href="/wiki/Allen_Klein" title="Allen Klein">Allen Klein</a>, who had managed <a href="/wiki/The_Rolling_Stones" title="The Rolling Stones">the Rolling Stones</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sam_Cooke" title="Sam Cooke">Sam Cooke</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a612_282-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a612-282">[273]</a></sup> McCartney wanted <a href="/wiki/Lee_Eastman" title="Lee Eastman">Lee</a> and John Eastman – father and brother, respectively, of <a href="/wiki/Linda_McCartney" title="Linda McCartney">Linda Eastman</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoggett201170,_132_283-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoggett201170,_132-283">[274]</a></sup> whom McCartney married on 12 March.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiles2001336_284-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiles2001336-284">[275]</a></sup> Agreement could not be reached, so both Klein and the Eastmans were temporarily appointed: Klein as the Beatles' business manager and the Eastmans as their lawyers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoggett201171–72_285-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoggett201171–72-285">[276]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGoodman2015164–166_286-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoodman2015164–166-286">[277]</a></sup> Further conflict ensued, however, and financial opportunities were lost.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a612_282-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a612-282">[273]</a></sup> On 8 May, Klein was named sole manager of the band,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992322_287-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992322-287">[278]</a></sup> the Eastmans having previously been dismissed as the Beatles' lawyers. McCartney refused to sign the management contract with Klein, but he was out-voted by the other Beatles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGoodman2015174–175_288-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoodman2015174–175-288">[279]</a></sup>
</p><p>Martin stated that he was surprised when McCartney asked him to produce another album, as the <i>Get Back</i> sessions had been "a miserable experience" and he had "thought it was the end of the road for all of us".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007560_289-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007560-289">[280]</a></sup> The primary recording sessions for <i>Abbey Road</i> began on 2 July.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992324_290-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992324-290">[281]</a></sup> Lennon, who rejected Martin's proposed format of a "continuously moving piece of music", wanted his and McCartney's songs to occupy separate sides of the album.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007563_291-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007563-291">[282]</a></sup> The eventual format, with individually composed songs on the first side and the second consisting largely of a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_musical_medleys" title="List of musical medleys">medley</a>, was McCartney's suggested compromise.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007563_291-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007563-291">[282]</a></sup> Emerick noted that the replacement of the studio's <a href="/wiki/Vacuum_tube" title="Vacuum tube">valve</a> mixing console with a transistorised one yielded a less punchy sound, leaving the group frustrated at the thinner tone and lack of impact and contributing to its "kinder, gentler" feel relative to their previous albums.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEmerickMassey2006277–278_292-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEmerickMassey2006277–278-292">[283]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 4 July, the first solo single by a Beatle was released: Lennon's "<a href="/wiki/Give_Peace_a_Chance" title="Give Peace a Chance">Give Peace a Chance</a>", credited to the <a href="/wiki/Plastic_Ono_Band" title="Plastic Ono Band">Plastic Ono Band</a>.
