The completion and mixing of "<a href="/wiki/I_Want_You_(She%27s_So_Heavy)" title="I Want You (She's So Heavy)">I Want You (She's So Heavy)</a>" on 20 August was the last occasion on which all four Beatles were together in the same studio.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1988191_293-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1988191-293">[284]</a></sup> On 8 September, while Starr was in hospital, the other band members met to discuss recording a new album. They considered a different approach to songwriting by ending the <a href="/wiki/Lennon%E2%80%93McCartney" title="Lennon–McCartney">Lennon–McCartney</a> pretence and having four compositions apiece from Lennon, McCartney and Harrison, with two from Starr and a lead single around Christmas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8sep69_294-0"><a href="#cite_note-8sep69-294">[285]</a></sup> On 20 September, Lennon announced his departure to the rest of the group but agreed to withhold a public announcement to avoid undermining sales of the forthcoming album.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENorman2008622–624_295-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorman2008622–624-295">[286]</a></sup>
</p><p>Released on 26 September, <i>Abbey Road</i> sold four million copies within three months and topped the UK charts for a total of seventeen weeks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007593_296-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007593-296">[287]</a></sup> Its second track, the ballad "<a href="/wiki/Something_(Beatles_song)" title="Something (Beatles song)">Something</a>", was issued as a single – the only Harrison composition that appeared as a Beatles A-side.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiles1997553_297-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiles1997553-297">[288]</a></sup> <i>Abbey Road</i> received mixed reviews, although the medley met with general acclaim.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007593_296-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007593-296">[287]</a></sup> Unterberger considers it "a fitting swan song for the group", containing "some of the greatest harmonies to be heard on any rock record".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[289]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Musicology" title="Musicology">Musicologist</a> and author <a href="/wiki/Ian_MacDonald" title="Ian MacDonald">Ian MacDonald</a> calls the album "erratic and often hollow", despite the "semblance of unity and coherence" offered by the medley.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMacDonald2005367_299-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMacDonald2005367-299">[290]</a></sup> Martin singled it out as his favourite Beatles album; Lennon said it was "competent" but had "no life in it".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEmerickMassey2006277–278_292-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEmerickMassey2006277–278-292">[283]</a></sup>
</p><p>For the still unfinished <i>Get Back</i> album, one last song, Harrison's "<a href="/wiki/I_Me_Mine" title="I Me Mine">I Me Mine</a>", was recorded on 3 January 1970. Lennon, in Denmark at the time, did not participate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992342_300-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992342-300">[291]</a></sup> In March, rejecting the work Johns had done on the project, now retitled <i>Let It Be</i>, Klein gave the session tapes to American producer <a href="/wiki/Phil_Spector" title="Phil Spector">Phil Spector</a>, who had recently produced Lennon's solo single "<a href="/wiki/Instant_Karma!" title="Instant Karma!">Instant Karma!</a>"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992342–343_301-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992342–343-301">[292]</a></sup> In addition to remixing the material, Spector edited, spliced and overdubbed several of the recordings that had been intended as "live". McCartney was unhappy with the producer's approach and particularly dissatisfied with the lavish orchestration on "<a href="/wiki/The_Long_and_Winding_Road" title="The Long and Winding Road">The Long and Winding Road</a>", which involved a fourteen-voice choir and 36-piece instrumental ensemble.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992349_302-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992349-302">[293]</a></sup> McCartney's demands that the alterations to the song be reverted were ignored,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a682_303-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a682-303">[294]</a></sup> and he publicly announced his departure from the band on 10 April, a week before the release of his first <a href="/wiki/McCartney_(album)" title="McCartney (album)">self-titled solo album</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992349_302-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992349-302">[293]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpitz2005853_304-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpitz2005853-304">[295]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 8 May 1970, <i>Let It Be</i> was released. Its accompanying single, "The Long and Winding Road", was the Beatles' last; it was released in the US, but not in the UK.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992350–351_186-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992350–351-186">[179]</a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Let_It_Be_(1970_film)" title="Let It Be (1970 film)">Let It Be</a></i> documentary film followed later that month, and would win the 1970 Academy Award for <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Score#1970s" title="Academy Award for Best Original Score">Best Original Song Score</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESouthallPerry200696_305-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESouthallPerry200696-305">[296]</a></sup> <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sunday_Telegraph" title="Sunday Telegraph">Sunday Telegraph</a></i> critic <a href="/wiki/Penelope_Gilliatt" title="Penelope Gilliatt">Penelope Gilliatt</a> called it "a very bad film and a touching one ... about the breaking apart of this reassuring, geometrically perfect, once apparently ageless family of siblings".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007600_306-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007600-306">[297]</a></sup> Several reviewers stated that some of the performances in the film sounded better than their analogous album tracks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007601_307-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007601-307">[298]</a></sup> Describing <i>Let It Be</i> as the "only Beatles album to occasion negative, even hostile reviews", Unterberger calls it "on the whole underrated"; he singles out "some good moments of straight hard rock in '<a href="/wiki/I%27ve_Got_a_Feeling" title="I've Got a Feeling">I've Got a Feeling</a>' and '<a href="/wiki/Dig_a_Pony" title="Dig a Pony">Dig a Pony</a>'", and praises "<a href="/wiki/Let_It_Be_(Beatles_song)" title="Let It Be (Beatles song)">Let It Be</a>", "Get Back", and "the folky '<a href="/wiki/Two_of_Us_(Beatles_song)" title="Two of Us (Beatles song)">Two of Us</a>', with John and Paul harmonising together".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[299]</a></sup>
</p><p>McCartney filed suit for the dissolution of the Beatles' contractual partnership on 31 December 1970.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2002139_309-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2002139-309">[300]</a></sup> Legal disputes continued long after their break-up, and the dissolution was not formalised until 29 December 1974,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2002150_310-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2002150-310">[301]</a></sup> when Lennon signed the paperwork terminating the partnership while on vacation with his family at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Walt_Disney_World_Resort" title="Walt Disney World Resort">Walt Disney World Resort</a> in Florida.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPang2008118_311-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPang2008118-311">[302]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="1970.E2.80.93present:_After_the_break-up"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1970–present:_After_the_break-up">1970–present: After the break-up</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Collaborations_between_ex-Beatles" title="Collaborations between ex-Beatles">Collaborations between ex-Beatles</a></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="1970s">1970s</span></h4>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:267px;max-width:267px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:131px;max-width:131px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:172px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:John_Lennon_last_television_interview_Tomorrow_show_1975_(34_cropped).JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="506" data-file-width="379" decoding="async" height="172" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/John_Lennon_last_television_interview_Tomorrow_show_1975_%2834_cropped%29.JPG/129px-John_Lennon_last_television_interview_Tomorrow_show_1975_%2834_cropped%29.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/John_Lennon_last_television_interview_Tomorrow_show_1975_%2834_cropped%29.JPG/194px-John_Lennon_last_television_interview_Tomorrow_show_1975_%2834_cropped%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/John_Lennon_last_television_interview_Tomorrow_show_1975_%2834_cropped%29.JPG/258px-John_Lennon_last_television_interview_Tomorrow_show_1975_%2834_cropped%29.JPG 2x" width="129"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:132px;max-width:132px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:172px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Paul_McCartney_during_a_Wings_concert,_1976_(34_cropped).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1673" data-file-width="1255" decoding="async" height="173" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Paul_McCartney_during_a_Wings_concert%2C_1976_%2834_cropped%29.jpg/130px-Paul_McCartney_during_a_Wings_concert%2C_1976_%2834_cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Paul_McCartney_during_a_Wings_concert%2C_1976_%2834_cropped%29.jpg/195px-Paul_McCartney_during_a_Wings_concert%2C_1976_%2834_cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Paul_McCartney_during_a_Wings_concert%2C_1976_%2834_cropped%29.jpg/260px-Paul_McCartney_during_a_Wings_concert%2C_1976_%2834_cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="130"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flow-root"><div class="thumbcaption" style="text-align:center">Lennon in 1975 and McCartney in 1976</div></div></div></div>
<p>Lennon, McCartney, Harrison and Starr all released solo albums in 1970. Their solo records sometimes involved one or more of the others;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007601–604_312-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007601–604-312">[303]</a></sup> Starr's <i><a href="/wiki/Ringo_(album)" title="Ringo (album)">Ringo</a></i> (1973) was the only album to include compositions and performances by all four ex-Beatles, albeit on separate songs. With Starr's participation, Harrison staged <a href="/wiki/The_Concert_for_Bangladesh" title="The Concert for Bangladesh">the Concert for Bangladesh</a> in New York City in August 1971.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007603–604_313-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007603–604-313">[304]</a></sup> Other than an unreleased jam session in 1974, later <a href="/wiki/Bootleg_recording" title="Bootleg recording">bootlegged</a> as <i><a href="/wiki/A_Toot_and_a_Snore_in_%2774" title="A Toot and a Snore in '74">A Toot and a Snore in '74</a></i>, Lennon and McCartney never recorded together again.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESandford2006227–229_314-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandford2006227–229-314">[305]</a></sup>
</p><p>Two double-LP sets of the Beatles' greatest hits, compiled by Klein, <i><a href="/wiki/1962%E2%80%931966" title="1962–1966">1962–1966</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/1967%E2%80%931970" title="1967–1970">1967–1970</a></i>, were released in 1973, at first under the Apple Records imprint.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEIngham200669_315-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIngham200669-315">[306]</a></sup> Commonly known as the "Red Album" and "Blue Album", respectively, each has earned a <a href="/wiki/Music_recording_certification" title="Music recording certification">Multi-Platinum certification</a> in the US and a Platinum certification in the UK.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RIAAb_316-0"><a href="#cite_note-RIAAb-316">[307]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BPI2009_317-0"><a href="#cite_note-BPI2009-317">[308]</a></sup> Between 1976 and 1982, EMI/Capitol released a wave of compilation albums without input from the ex-Beatles, starting with the double-disc compilation <i><a href="/wiki/Rock_%27n%27_Roll_Music_(album)" title="Rock 'n' Roll Music (album)">Rock 'n' Roll Music</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESouthallPerry2006109_318-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESouthallPerry2006109-318">[309]</a></sup> The only one to feature previously unreleased material was <i><a href="/wiki/The_Beatles_at_the_Hollywood_Bowl" title="The Beatles at the Hollywood Bowl">The Beatles at the Hollywood Bowl</a></i> (1977); the first officially issued concert recordings by the group, it contained selections from two shows they played during their 1964 and 1965 US tours.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEIngham200666,_69_319-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIngham200666,_69-319">[310]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[nb 10]</a></sup>
</p><p>The music and enduring fame of the Beatles were commercially exploited in various other ways, again often outside their creative control. In April 1974, the musical <i><a href="/wiki/John,_Paul,_George,_Ringo_..._and_Bert" title="John, Paul, George, Ringo ... and Bert">John, Paul, George, Ringo ... and Bert</a></i>, written by <a href="/wiki/Willy_Russell" title="Willy Russell">Willy Russell</a> and featuring singer <a href="/wiki/Barbara_Dickson" title="Barbara Dickson">Barbara Dickson</a>, opened in London. It included, with permission from Northern Songs, eleven Lennon-McCartney compositions and one by Harrison, "<a href="/wiki/Here_Comes_the_Sun" title="Here Comes the Sun">Here Comes the Sun</a>". Displeased with the production's use of his song, Harrison withdrew his permission to use it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESouthallPerry2006109–110_322-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESouthallPerry2006109–110-322">[312]</a></sup> Later that year, the off-Broadway musical <i><a href="/wiki/Sgt._Pepper%27s_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band_on_the_Road" title="Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band on the Road">Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band on the Road</a></i> opened.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[313]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/All_This_and_World_War_II" title="All This and World War II">All This and World War II</a></i> (1976) was an unorthodox nonfiction film that combined newsreel footage with covers of Beatles songs by performers ranging from <a href="/wiki/Elton_John" title="Elton John">Elton John</a> and <a href="/wiki/Keith_Moon" title="Keith Moon">Keith Moon</a> to the <a href="/wiki/London_Symphony_Orchestra" title="London Symphony Orchestra">London Symphony Orchestra</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERodriguez2010306–307_324-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERodriguez2010306–307-324">[314]</a></sup> The Broadway musical <i><a href="/wiki/Beatlemania_(musical)" title="Beatlemania (musical)">Beatlemania</a></i>, an unauthorised nostalgia revue, opened in early 1977 and proved popular, spinning off five separate touring productions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEIngham200666–67_325-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIngham200666–67-325">[315]</a></sup> In 1979, the band sued the producers, settling for several million dollars in damages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEIngham200666–67_325-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIngham200666–67-325">[315]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Sgt._Pepper%27s_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band_(film)" title="Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band (film)">Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band</a></i> (1978), a musical film starring the <a href="/wiki/Bee_Gees" title="Bee Gees">Bee Gees</a> and <a href="/wiki/Peter_Frampton" title="Peter Frampton">Peter Frampton</a>, was a commercial failure and an "artistic fiasco", according to Ingham.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEIngham200666_326-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIngham200666-326">[316]</a></sup>
</p><p>Accompanying the wave of Beatles nostalgia and persistent reunion rumours in the US during the 1970s, several entrepreneurs made public offers to the Beatles for a reunion concert.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchaffner1978169–72_327-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchaffner1978169–72-327">[317]</a></sup> Promoter Bill Sargent first offered the Beatles $10 million for a reunion concert in 1974. He raised his offer to $30 million in January 1976 and then to $50 million the following month.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[318]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[319]</a></sup> On 24 April 1976, during a broadcast of <i><a href="/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live" title="Saturday Night Live">Saturday Night Live</a></i>, producer <a href="/wiki/Lorne_Michaels" title="Lorne Michaels">Lorne Michaels</a> jokingly offered the Beatles $3,000 to reunite on the show. Lennon and McCartney were watching the live broadcast at Lennon's apartment at <a href="/wiki/The_Dakota" title="The Dakota">the Dakota</a> in New York, which was within driving distance of the <a href="/wiki/Studio_8H" title="Studio 8H">NBC studio</a> where the show was being broadcast. The former bandmates briefly entertained the idea of going to the studio and surprising Michaels by accepting his offer, but decided not to.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoggett2011155_330-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoggett2011155-330">[320]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="1980s">1980s</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:242px;max-width:242px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:119px;max-width:119px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:156px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:George-Harrison-playing_(tall_crop).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="275" data-file-width="206" decoding="async" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/George-Harrison-playing_%28tall_crop%29.jpg/117px-George-Harrison-playing_%28tall_crop%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/George-Harrison-playing_%28tall_crop%29.jpg/176px-George-Harrison-playing_%28tall_crop%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/14/George-Harrison-playing_%28tall_crop%29.jpg 2x" width="117"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:119px;max-width:119px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:156px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ringo_Princes_Trust_(tall_crop).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="705" data-file-width="528" decoding="async" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Ringo_Princes_Trust_%28tall_crop%29.jpg/117px-Ringo_Princes_Trust_%28tall_crop%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Ringo_Princes_Trust_%28tall_crop%29.jpg/176px-Ringo_Princes_Trust_%28tall_crop%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Ringo_Princes_Trust_%28tall_crop%29.jpg/234px-Ringo_Princes_Trust_%28tall_crop%29.jpg 2x" width="117"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flow-root"><div class="thumbcaption" style="text-align:center">Harrison and Starr performing at <a href="/wiki/The_Prince%27s_Trust" title="The Prince's Trust">the Prince's Trust</a> All-Star Rock Concert at <a href="/wiki/Wembley_Arena" title="Wembley Arena">Wembley Arena</a>, 1987</div></div></div></div>
<p>In December 1980, Lennon was <a href="/wiki/Murder_of_John_Lennon" title="Murder of John Lennon">shot and killed</a> outside his New York City apartment. Harrison rewrote the lyrics of his song "<a href="/wiki/All_Those_Years_Ago" title="All Those Years Ago">All Those Years Ago</a>" in Lennon's honour. With Starr on drums and McCartney and his wife, <a href="/wiki/Linda_McCartney" title="Linda McCartney">Linda</a>, contributing backing vocals, the song was released as a single in May 1981.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBadman1999284_331-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBadman1999284-331">[321]</a></sup> McCartney's own tribute, "<a href="/wiki/Here_Today_(Paul_McCartney_song)" title="Here Today (Paul McCartney song)">Here Today</a>", appeared on his <i><a href="/wiki/Tug_of_War_(Paul_McCartney_album)" title="Tug of War (Paul McCartney album)">Tug of War</a></i> album in April 1982.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2002412–413_332-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2002412–413-332">[322]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1984 Starr co-starred with McCartney in Paul's film <i><a href="/wiki/Give_My_Regards_to_Broad_Street_(film)" title="Give My Regards to Broad Street (film)">Give My Regards to Broad Street</a></i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[323]</a></sup> and played with Paul on several of the songs on the <a href="/wiki/Give_My_Regards_to_Broad_Street" title="Give My Regards to Broad Street">soundtrack</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334">[324]</a></sup> In 1987, Harrison's <i><a href="/wiki/Cloud_Nine_(George_Harrison_album)" title="Cloud Nine (George Harrison album)">Cloud Nine</a></i> album included "<a href="/wiki/When_We_Was_Fab" title="When We Was Fab">When We Was Fab</a>", a song about the Beatlemania era.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoggett2009292_335-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoggett2009292-335">[325]</a></sup>
</p><p>When the Beatles' studio albums were released on CD by EMI and Apple Corps in 1987, their catalogue was standardised throughout the world, establishing a canon of the twelve original studio LPs as issued in the UK plus the US LP version of <i>Magical Mystery Tour</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EMI_2009_336-0"><a href="#cite_note-EMI_2009-336">[326]</a></sup> All the remaining material from the singles and EPs that had not appeared on these thirteen studio albums was gathered on the two-volume compilation <i><a href="/wiki/Past_Masters" title="Past Masters">Past Masters</a></i> (1988). Except for the <i>Red</i> and <i>Blue</i> albums, EMI deleted all its other Beatles compilations – including the <i>Hollywood Bowl</i> record – from its catalogue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEIngham200666,_69_319-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIngham200666,_69-319">[310]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1988, the Beatles were inducted into the <a href="/wiki/Rock_and_Roll_Hall_of_Fame" title="Rock and Roll Hall of Fame">Rock and Roll Hall of Fame</a>, their first year of eligibility. Harrison and Starr attended the ceremony with Lennon's widow, Yoko Ono, and his two sons, <a href="/wiki/Julian_Lennon" title="Julian Lennon">Julian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sean_Lennon" title="Sean Lennon">Sean</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-R&amp;R_HoF_337-0"><a href="#cite_note-R&amp;R_HoF-337">[327]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2002753_338-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2002753-338">[328]</a></sup> McCartney declined to attend, citing unresolved "business differences" that would make him "feel like a complete hypocrite waving and smiling with them at a fake reunion".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2002753_338-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2002753-338">[328]</a></sup> The following year, EMI/Capitol settled a decade-long lawsuit filed by the band over royalties, clearing the way to commercially package previously unreleased material.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[329]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2002192_340-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2002192-340">[330]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="1990s">1990s</span></h4>
<p><i><a href="/wiki/Live_at_the_BBC_(Beatles_album)" title="Live at the BBC (Beatles album)">Live at the BBC</a></i>, the first official release of unissued Beatles performances in seventeen years, appeared in 1994.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a661–663_341-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a661–663-341">[331]</a></sup> That same year McCartney, Harrison and Starr collaborated on the <i><a href="/wiki/The_Beatles_Anthology" title="The Beatles Anthology">Anthology</a></i> project. <i>Anthology</i> was the culmination of work begun in 1970, when Apple Corps director <a href="/wiki/Neil_Aspinall" title="Neil Aspinall">Neil Aspinall</a>, their former road manager and personal assistant, had started to gather material for a documentary with the working title <i>The Long and Winding Road</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a110–111_342-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a110–111-342">[332]</a></sup> Documenting their history in the band's own words, the <i>Anthology</i> project included the release of several unissued Beatles recordings. McCartney, Harrison and Starr also added new instrumental and vocal parts to songs recorded as demos by Lennon in the late 1970s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a111–112,_428,_907–908_343-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a111–112,_428,_907–908-343">[333]</a></sup>
</p><p>During 1995–96, the project yielded a television miniseries, an eight-volume video set, and three two-CD/three-LP box sets featuring artwork by Klaus Voormann. Two songs based on Lennon demos, "<a href="/wiki/Free_as_a_Bird" title="Free as a Bird">Free as a Bird</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/Real_Love_(Beatles_song)" title="Real Love (Beatles song)">Real Love</a>", were issued as new Beatles singles. The releases were commercially successful and the television series was viewed by an estimated 400 million people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a111–112_344-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a111–112-344">[334]</a></sup> In 1999, to coincide with the re-release of the 1968 film <i>Yellow Submarine</i>, an expanded soundtrack album, <i><a href="/wiki/Yellow_Submarine_Songtrack" title="Yellow Submarine Songtrack">Yellow Submarine Songtrack</a></i>, was issued.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoggett2009342_345-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoggett2009342-345">[335]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="2000s">2000s</span></h4>
<p>The Beatles' <i><a href="/wiki/1_(Beatles_album)" title="1 (Beatles album)">1</a></i>, a compilation album of the band's British and American number-one hits, was released on 13 November 2000. It became the fastest-selling album of all time, with 3.6 million sold in its first week<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[336]</a></sup> and 13 million within a month.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould20079_347-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould20079-347">[337]</a></sup> It topped albums charts in at least 28 countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESouthallPerry2006204_348-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESouthallPerry2006204-348">[338]</a></sup> The compilation had sold 31 million copies globally by April 2009.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[339]</a></sup>
</p><p>Harrison died from <a href="/wiki/Metastasis" title="Metastasis">metastatic</a> lung cancer in November 2001.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350">[340]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[341]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2003119_352-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2003119-352">[342]</a></sup> McCartney and Starr were among the musicians who performed at the <a href="/wiki/Concert_for_George" title="Concert for George">Concert for George</a>, organised by <a href="/wiki/Eric_Clapton" title="Eric Clapton">Eric Clapton</a> and Harrison's widow, <a href="/wiki/Olivia_Harrison" title="Olivia Harrison">Olivia</a>. The tribute event took place at the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Albert_Hall" title="Royal Albert Hall">Royal Albert Hall</a> on the first anniversary of Harrison's death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2003138–139_353-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2003138–139-353">[343]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2003, <i><a href="/wiki/Let_It_Be..._Naked" title="Let It Be... Naked">Let It Be... Naked</a></i>, a reconceived version of the <i>Let It Be</i> album, with McCartney supervising production, was released. One of the main differences from the Spector-produced version was the omission of the original string arrangements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354"><a href="#cite_note-354">[344]</a></sup> It was a top-ten hit in both Britain and America. The US album configurations from 1964 to 1965 were released as box sets in 2004 and 2006; <i><a href="/wiki/The_Capitol_Albums,_Volume_1" title="The Capitol Albums, Volume 1">The Capitol Albums, Volume 1</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Capitol_Albums,_Volume_2" title="The Capitol Albums, Volume 2">Volume 2</a></i> included both stereo and mono versions based on the mixes that were prepared for vinyl at the time of the music's original American release.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWomack2007100_355-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWomack2007100-355">[345]</a></sup>
</p><p>As a soundtrack for <a href="/wiki/Cirque_du_Soleil" title="Cirque du Soleil">Cirque du Soleil</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Las_Vegas_Strip" title="Las Vegas Strip">Las Vegas</a> Beatles stage revue, <i><a href="/wiki/Love_(Cirque_du_Soleil)" title="Love (Cirque du Soleil)">Love</a></i>, George Martin and his son <a href="/wiki/Giles_Martin" title="Giles Martin">Giles</a> remixed and <a href="/wiki/Mashup_(music)" title="Mashup (music)">blended</a> 130 of the band's recordings to create what Martin called "a way of re-living the whole Beatles musical lifespan in a very condensed period".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[346]</a></sup> The show premiered in June 2006, and the <i><a href="/wiki/Love_(Beatles_album)" title="Love (Beatles album)">Love</a></i> album was released that November.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[347]</a></sup> In April 2009, Starr performed three songs with McCartney at a benefit concert held at New York's <a href="/wiki/Radio_City_Music_Hall" title="Radio City Music Hall">Radio City Music Hall</a> and organised by McCartney.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[348]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 9 September 2009, the Beatles' entire back catalogue was reissued following an extensive digital remastering process that lasted four years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EMI_2009_336-1"><a href="#cite_note-EMI_2009-336">[326]</a></sup> Stereo editions of all twelve original UK studio albums, along with <i>Magical Mystery Tour</i> and the <i>Past Masters</i> compilation, were released on compact disc both individually and <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles_(The_Original_Studio_Recordings)" title="The Beatles (The Original Studio Recordings)">as a box set</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[349]</a></sup> A second collection, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Beatles_in_Mono" title="The Beatles in Mono">The Beatles in Mono</a></i>, included remastered versions of every Beatles album released in true mono along with the original 1965 stereo mixes of <i>Help!</i> and <i>Rubber Soul</i> (both of which Martin had remixed for the 1987 editions).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[350]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Beatles:_Rock_Band" title="The Beatles: Rock Band">The Beatles: Rock Band</a></i>, a music video game in the <i><a href="/wiki/Rock_Band" title="Rock Band">Rock Band</a></i> series, was issued on the same day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNN_Gross_361-0"><a href="#cite_note-CNN_Gross-361">[351]</a></sup> In December 2009, the band's catalogue was officially released in <a href="/wiki/FLAC" title="FLAC">FLAC</a> and <a href="/wiki/MP3" title="MP3">MP3</a> format in <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles_(The_Original_Studio_Recordings)#Limited_edition_USB_flash_drive" title="The Beatles (The Original Studio Recordings)">a limited edition of 30,000 USB flash drives</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362"><a href="#cite_note-362">[352]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="2010s">2010s</span></h4>
<p>Owing to a long-running royalty disagreement, the Beatles were among the last major artists to sign deals with online music services.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363"><a href="#cite_note-363">[353]</a></sup> Residual disagreement emanating from <a href="/wiki/Apple_Corps_v_Apple_Computer" title="Apple Corps v Apple Computer">Apple Corps' dispute with Apple, Inc.</a>, <a href="/wiki/ITunes" title="ITunes">iTunes</a>' owners, over the use of the name "Apple" was also partly responsible for the delay, although in 2008, McCartney stated that the main obstacle to making the Beatles' catalogue available online was that EMI "want[s] something we're not prepared to give them".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364"><a href="#cite_note-364">[354]</a></sup> In 2010, the official canon of thirteen Beatles studio albums, <i>Past Masters</i>, and the "Red" and "Blue" greatest-hits albums were made available on iTunes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[355]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2012, EMI's recorded music operations were sold to <a href="/wiki/Universal_Music_Group" title="Universal Music Group">Universal Music Group</a>. In order for Universal Music to acquire EMI, the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>, for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Antitrust" title="Antitrust">antitrust</a> reasons, forced EMI to spin off assets including Parlophone. Universal was allowed to keep the Beatles' recorded music catalogue, managed by <a href="/wiki/Capitol_Records" title="Capitol Records">Capitol Records</a> under its <a href="/wiki/Capitol_Music_Group" title="Capitol Music Group">Capitol Music Group</a> division.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[356]</a></sup> The entire original Beatles album catalogue was also reissued on vinyl in 2012; available either individually or as a box set.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[357]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2013, a second volume of BBC recordings, titled <i><a href="/wiki/On_Air_%E2%80%93_Live_at_the_BBC_Volume_2" title="On Air – Live at the BBC Volume 2">On Air – Live at the BBC Volume 2</a></i>, was released. That December saw the release of another 59 Beatles recordings on iTunes. The set, titled <i><a href="/wiki/The_Beatles_Bootleg_Recordings_1963" title="The Beatles Bootleg Recordings 1963">The Beatles Bootleg Recordings 1963</a></i>, had the opportunity to gain a 70-year copyright extension conditional on the songs being published at least once before the end of 2013. Apple Records released the recordings on 17 December to prevent them from going into the public domain and had them taken down from iTunes later that same day. Fan reactions to the release were mixed, with one blogger saying "the hardcore Beatles collectors who are trying to obtain everything will already have these."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[358]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[359]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 26 January 2014, McCartney and Starr performed together at the <a href="/wiki/56th_Annual_Grammy_Awards" title="56th Annual Grammy Awards">56th Annual Grammy Awards</a>, held at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Staples_Center" title="Staples Center">Staples Center</a> in <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[360]</a></sup> The following day, <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Night_That_Changed_America:_A_Grammy_Salute_to_The_Beatles" title="The Night That Changed America: A Grammy Salute to The Beatles">The Night That Changed America: A Grammy Salute to The Beatles</a></i> television special was taped in the <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Convention_Center" title="Los Angeles Convention Center">Los Angeles Convention Center</a>'s West Hall. It aired on 9 February, the exact date of – and at the same time, and on the same network as – the original broadcast of the Beatles' first US television appearance on <i>The Ed Sullivan Show</i>, 50 years earlier. The special included performances of Beatles songs by current artists as well as by McCartney and Starr, archival footage, and interviews with the two surviving ex-Beatles carried out by <a href="/wiki/David_Letterman" title="David Letterman">David Letterman</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Ed_Sullivan_Theater" title="Ed Sullivan Theater">Ed Sullivan Theater</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[361]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[362]</a></sup> In December 2015, the Beatles released their catalogue for streaming on various streaming music services including <a href="/wiki/Spotify" title="Spotify">Spotify</a> and <a href="/wiki/Apple_Music" title="Apple Music">Apple Music</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[363]</a></sup>
</p><p>In September 2016, the documentary film <i><a href="/wiki/The_Beatles:_Eight_Days_a_Week" title="The Beatles: Eight Days a Week">The Beatles: Eight Days a Week</a></i> was released. Directed by <a href="/wiki/Ron_Howard" title="Ron Howard">Ron Howard</a>, it chronicled the Beatles' career during their touring years from 1961 to 1966, from their performances in Liverpool's the Cavern Club in 1961 to their final concert in San Francisco in 1966. The film was released theatrically on 15 September in the UK and the US, and started streaming on <a href="/wiki/Hulu" title="Hulu">Hulu</a> on 17 September. It received several awards and nominations, including for Best Documentary at the 70th British Academy Film Awards and the Outstanding Documentary or Nonfiction Special at the 69th Primetime Creative Arts Emmy Awards.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[364]</a></sup> An expanded, remixed and remastered version of <i>The Beatles at the Hollywood Bowl</i> was released on 9 September, to coincide with the release of the film.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[365]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376"><a href="#cite_note-376">[366]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 18 May 2017, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sirius_XM_Radio" title="Sirius XM Radio">Sirius XM Radio</a> launched a 24/7 radio channel, The Beatles Channel. A week later, <i>Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band</i> was reissued with new stereo mixes and unreleased material for the album's 50th anniversary.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377"><a href="#cite_note-377">[367]</a></sup> Similar box sets were released for <i>The Beatles</i> in November 2018,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[368]</a></sup> and <i>Abbey Road</i> in September 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[369]</a></sup> On the first week of October 2019, <i>Abbey Road</i> returned to number one on the UK Albums Chart. The Beatles broke their own record for the album with the longest gap between topping the charts as <i>Abbey Road</i> hit the top spot 50 years after its original release.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[370]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="2020s">2020s</span></h4>
<p>In November 2021, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Beatles:_Get_Back" title="The Beatles: Get Back">The Beatles: Get Back</a></i>, a documentary directed by <a href="/wiki/Peter_Jackson" title="Peter Jackson">Peter Jackson</a> using footage captured for the <i>Let It Be</i> film, was released on <a href="/wiki/Disney%2B" title="Disney+">Disney+</a> as a three-part <a href="/wiki/Miniseries" title="Miniseries">miniseries</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[371]</a></sup> A book also titled <i>The Beatles: Get Back</i> was released on 12 October, ahead of the documentary.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[372]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Let_It_Be:_Special_Edition" title="Let It Be: Special Edition">super deluxe version</a> of the <i><a href="/wiki/Let_It_Be_(Beatles_album)" title="Let It Be (Beatles album)">Let It Be</a></i> album was released on 15 October.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[373]</a></sup> In January 2022, an album titled <i>Get Back (Rooftop Performance)</i>, consisting of newly mixed audio of the <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles%27_rooftop_concert" title="The Beatles' rooftop concert">Beatles' rooftop performance</a>, was released on streaming services.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[374]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Musical_style_and_development">Musical style and development</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Lennon%E2%80%93McCartney" title="Lennon–McCartney">Lennon–McCartney</a></div>
<p>In <i>Icons of Rock: An Encyclopedia of the Legends Who Changed Music Forever</i>, Scott Schinder and Andy Schwartz describe the Beatles' musical evolution:
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>In their initial incarnation as cheerful, wisecracking moptops, the Fab Four revolutionised the sound, style, and attitude of popular music and opened rock and roll's doors to a tidal wave of British rock acts. Their initial impact would have been enough to establish the Beatles as one of their era's most influential cultural forces, but they didn't stop there. Although their initial style was a highly original, irresistibly catchy synthesis of early American rock and roll and R&amp;B, the Beatles spent the rest of the 1960s expanding rock's stylistic frontiers, consistently staking out new musical territory on each release. The band's increasingly sophisticated experimentation encompassed a variety of genres, including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Folk-rock" title="Folk-rock">folk-rock</a>, <a href="/wiki/Country_music" title="Country music">country</a>, <a href="/wiki/Psychedelic_music" title="Psychedelic music">psychedelia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Baroque_pop" title="Baroque pop">baroque pop</a>, without sacrificing the effortless mass appeal of their early work.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchinderSchwartz2007160_385-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchinderSchwartz2007160-385">[375]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>In <i>The Beatles as Musicians</i>, <a href="/wiki/Walter_Everett_(musicologist)" title="Walter Everett (musicologist)">Walter Everett</a> describes Lennon and McCartney's contrasting motivations and approaches to composition: "McCartney may be said to have constantly developed – as a means to entertain – a focused musical talent with an ear for counterpoint and other aspects of craft in the demonstration of a universally agreed-upon common language that he did much to enrich. Conversely, Lennon's mature music is best appreciated as the daring product of a largely unconscious, searching but undisciplined artistic sensibility."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEverett19999_386-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEverett19999-386">[376]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ian MacDonald describes McCartney as "a natural melodist – a creator of tunes capable of existing apart from their harmony". His melody lines are characterised as primarily "vertical", employing wide, <a href="/wiki/Consonance_and_dissonance" title="Consonance and dissonance">consonant</a> intervals which express his "extrovert energy and optimism". Conversely, Lennon's "sedentary, ironic personality" is reflected in a "horizontal" approach featuring minimal, dissonant intervals and repetitive melodies which rely on their harmonic accompaniment for interest: "Basically a realist, he instinctively kept his melodies close to the rhythms and cadences of speech, colouring his lyrics with bluesy tone and harmony rather than creating tunes that made striking shapes of their own."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMacDonald200512_387-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMacDonald200512-387">[377]</a></sup> MacDonald praises Harrison's lead guitar work for the role his "characterful lines and textural colourings" play in supporting Lennon and McCartney's parts, and describes Starr as "the father of modern pop/rock drumming".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMacDonald2005382–383_388-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMacDonald2005382–383-388">[378]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Influences">Influences</span></h3>
<p>The Beatles' earliest influences include Elvis Presley, <a href="/wiki/Carl_Perkins" title="Carl Perkins">Carl Perkins</a>, <a href="/wiki/Little_Richard" title="Little Richard">Little Richard</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chuck_Berry" title="Chuck Berry">Chuck Berry</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a140,_660,_856–858,_881_389-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a140,_660,_856–858,_881-389">[379]</a></sup> During the Beatles' co-residency with Little Richard at the <a href="/wiki/Star-Club" title="Star-Club">Star-Club</a> in Hamburg, from April to May 1962, he advised them on the proper technique for performing his songs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a660_390-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a660-390">[380]</a></sup> Of Presley, Lennon said, "Nothing really affected me until I heard Elvis. If there hadn't been Elvis, there would not have been the Beatles."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a881_391-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a881-391">[381]</a></sup> Other early influences include Buddy Holly, <a href="/wiki/Eddie_Cochran" title="Eddie Cochran">Eddie Cochran</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roy_Orbison" title="Roy Orbison">Roy Orbison</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a289,_526,_830_392-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a289,_526,_830-392">[382]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/The_Everly_Brothers" title="The Everly Brothers">the Everly Brothers</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpitz2005111,_123,_131,_133_393-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpitz2005111,_123,_131,_133-393">[383]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Beatles continued to absorb influences long after their initial success, often finding new musical and lyrical avenues by listening to their contemporaries, including <a href="/wiki/Bob_Dylan" title="Bob Dylan">Bob Dylan</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Who" title="The Who">the Who</a>, <a href="/wiki/Frank_Zappa" title="Frank Zappa">Frank Zappa</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Lovin%27_Spoonful" title="The Lovin' Spoonful">the Lovin' Spoonful</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Byrds" title="The Byrds">the Byrds</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Beach_Boys" title="The Beach Boys">the Beach Boys</a>, whose 1966 album <i><a href="/wiki/Pet_Sounds" title="Pet Sounds">Pet Sounds</a></i> amazed and inspired McCartney.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a99,_217,_357,_1195_394-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a99,_217,_357,_1195-394">[384]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007333–335,_359_395-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007333–335,_359-395">[385]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELavezzoli2006147,_150,_162,_169_396-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELavezzoli2006147,_150,_162,_169-396">[386]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[387]</a></sup> Referring to the Beach Boys' creative leader, Martin later stated: "No one made a greater impact on the Beatles than Brian [Wilson]."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGranata200317_398-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGranata200317-398">[388]</a></sup> Ravi Shankar, with whom Harrison studied for six weeks in India in late 1966, had a significant effect on his musical development during the band's later years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELavezzoli2006147,_165,_177_399-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELavezzoli2006147,_165,_177-399">[389]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Genres">Genres</span></h3>
<p>Originating as a skiffle group, the Beatles quickly embraced 1950s rock and roll and helped pioneer the Merseybeat genre,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[390]</a></sup> and their repertoire ultimately expanded to include a broad variety of pop music.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould200730–32,_100–107_401-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould200730–32,_100–107-401">[391]</a></sup> Reflecting the range of styles they explored, Lennon said of <i>Beatles for Sale</i>, "You could call our new one a Beatles country-and-western LP",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007255_402-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007255-402">[392]</a></sup> while Gould credits <i>Rubber Soul</i> as "the instrument by which legions of folk-music enthusiasts were coaxed into the camp of pop".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007296_403-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007296-403">[393]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Guitarras_de_McCartney_y_Harrison.jpg"><img alt="Two electric guitars, a light brown violin-shaped bass and a darker brown guitar resting against a Vox amplifier" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1280" data-file-width="853" decoding="async" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Guitarras_de_McCartney_y_Harrison.jpg/170px-Guitarras_de_McCartney_y_Harrison.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Guitarras_de_McCartney_y_Harrison.jpg/255px-Guitarras_de_McCartney_y_Harrison.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Guitarras_de_McCartney_y_Harrison.jpg/340px-Guitarras_de_McCartney_y_Harrison.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Guitarras_de_McCartney_y_Harrison.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/H%C3%B6fner_500/1" title="Höfner 500/1">Höfner "violin" bass guitar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gretsch" title="Gretsch">Gretsch Country Gentleman guitar</a>, models played by McCartney and Harrison, respectively; the <a href="/wiki/Vox_AC30" title="Vox AC30">Vox AC30</a> amplifier behind them is the model the Beatles used during performances in the early 1960s.</div></div></div>
<p>Although the 1965 song "Yesterday" was not the first pop record to employ orchestral strings, it marked the group's first recorded use of classical music elements. Gould observes: "The more traditional sound of strings allowed for a fresh appreciation of their talent as composers by listeners who were otherwise allergic to the din of drums and electric guitars."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007278_404-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007278-404">[394]</a></sup> They continued to experiment with string arrangements to various effect; <i>Sgt. Pepper</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s "<a href="/wiki/She%27s_Leaving_Home" title="She's Leaving Home">She's Leaving Home</a>", for instance, is "cast in the <span title="American English-language text"><span lang="en-US">mold</span></span> of a sentimental Victorian ballad", Gould writes, "its words and music filled with the clichés of musical melodrama".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007402_405-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007402-405">[395]</a></sup>
</p><p>The band's stylistic range expanded in another direction with their 1966 B-side "Rain", described by <a href="/wiki/Martin_C._Strong" title="Martin C. Strong">Martin Strong</a> as "the first overtly psychedelic Beatles record".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStrong2004108_406-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStrong2004108-406">[396]</a></sup> Other psychedelic numbers followed, such as "Tomorrow Never Knows" (recorded before "Rain"), "Strawberry Fields Forever", "<a href="/wiki/Lucy_in_the_Sky_with_Diamonds" title="Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds">Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/I_Am_the_Walrus" title="I Am the Walrus">I Am the Walrus</a>". The influence of <a href="/wiki/Indian_classical_music" title="Indian classical music">Indian classical music</a> was evident in Harrison's "<a href="/wiki/The_Inner_Light_(song)" title="The Inner Light (song)">The Inner Light</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Love_You_To" title="Love You To">Love You To</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/Within_You_Without_You" title="Within You Without You">Within You Without You</a>" – Gould describes the latter two as attempts "to replicate the <a href="/wiki/Raga" title="Raga">raga</a> form in miniature".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007406,_462–463_407-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007406,_462–463-407">[397]</a></sup>
</p><p>Innovation was the most striking feature of their creative evolution, according to music historian and pianist Michael Campbell: "'A Day in the Life' encapsulates the art and achievement of the Beatles as well as any single track can. It highlights key features of their music: the sound imagination, the persistence of tuneful melody, and the close coordination between words and music. It represents a new category of song – more sophisticated than pop ... and uniquely innovative. There literally had never before been a song – classical or vernacular – that had blended so many disparate elements so imaginatively."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECampbell2008196_408-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampbell2008196-408">[398]</a></sup> Philosophy professor Bruce Ellis Benson agrees: "the Beatles ... give us a wonderful example of how such far-ranging influences as Celtic music, rhythm and blues, and country and western could be put together in a new way."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBenson200343_409-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBenson200343-409">[399]</a></sup>
</p><p>Author Dominic Pedler describes the way they crossed musical styles: "Far from moving sequentially from one genre to another (as is sometimes conveniently suggested) the group maintained <i>in parallel</i> their mastery of the traditional, catchy chart hit while simultaneously forging rock and dabbling with a wide range of peripheral influences from country to vaudeville. One of these threads was their take on folk music, which would form such essential groundwork for their later collisions with Indian music and philosophy."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPedler2003256_410-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPedler2003256-410">[400]</a></sup> As the personal relationships between the band members grew increasingly strained, their individual tastes became more apparent. The minimalistic cover artwork for the White Album contrasted with the complexity and diversity of its music, which encompassed Lennon's "<a href="/wiki/Revolution_9" title="Revolution 9">Revolution 9</a>" (whose <a href="/wiki/Musique_concr%C3%A8te" title="Musique concrète">musique concrète</a> approach was influenced by Yoko Ono), Starr's <a href="/wiki/Country_music" title="Country music">country</a> song "<a href="/wiki/Don%27t_Pass_Me_By" title="Don't Pass Me By">Don't Pass Me By</a>", Harrison's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rock_ballad" title="Rock ballad">rock ballad</a> "<a href="/wiki/While_My_Guitar_Gently_Weeps" title="While My Guitar Gently Weeps">While My Guitar Gently Weeps</a>", and the "<a href="/wiki/Heavy_metal_music#Origins:_late_1960s_and_early_1970s" title="Heavy metal music">proto-metal</a> roar" of McCartney's "<a href="/wiki/Helter_Skelter_(song)" title="Helter Skelter (song)">Helter Skelter</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-White_Album_AllMusic_411-0"><a href="#cite_note-White_Album_AllMusic-411">[401]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Contribution_of_George_Martin">Contribution of George Martin</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Beatles_and_George_Martin_in_studio_1966.JPG"><img alt="The Beatles with George Martin in the studio in the mid-1960s" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="627" data-file-width="951" decoding="async" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Beatles_and_George_Martin_in_studio_1966.JPG/220px-Beatles_and_George_Martin_in_studio_1966.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Beatles_and_George_Martin_in_studio_1966.JPG/330px-Beatles_and_George_Martin_in_studio_1966.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Beatles_and_George_Martin_in_studio_1966.JPG/440px-Beatles_and_George_Martin_in_studio_1966.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Beatles_and_George_Martin_in_studio_1966.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Martin (second from right) in the studio with the Beatles in the mid-1960s</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/George_Martin" title="George Martin">George Martin</a>'s close involvement in his role as producer made him one of the leading candidates for the informal title of the "<a href="/wiki/Fifth_Beatle" title="Fifth Beatle">fifth Beatle</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a721_412-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2000a721-412">[402]</a></sup> He applied his classical musical training in various ways, and functioned as "an informal music teacher" to the progressing songwriters, according to Gould.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007121,_290_413-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007121,_290-413">[403]</a></sup> Martin suggested to a sceptical McCartney that the arrangement of "Yesterday" should feature a string quartet accompaniment, thereby introducing the Beatles to a "hitherto unsuspected world of classical instrumental colour", in MacDonald's description.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMacDonald2005158_414-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMacDonald2005158-414">[404]</a></sup> Their creative development was also facilitated by Martin's willingness to experiment in response to their suggestions, such as adding "something <a href="/wiki/Baroque_music" title="Baroque music">baroque</a>" to a particular recording.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007290_415-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007290-415">[405]</a></sup> In addition to scoring orchestral arrangements for recordings, Martin often performed on them, playing instruments including piano, organ and <a href="/wiki/Brass_instrument" title="Brass instrument">brass</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007382,_405,_409,_443,_584_416-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007382,_405,_409,_443,_584-416">[406]</a></sup>
</p><p>Collaborating with Lennon and McCartney required Martin to adapt to their different approaches to songwriting and recording. MacDonald comments, "while [he] worked more naturally with the conventionally articulate McCartney, the challenge of catering to Lennon's intuitive approach generally spurred him to his more original arrangements, of which "<a href="/wiki/Being_for_the_Benefit_of_Mr._Kite!" title="Being for the Benefit of Mr. Kite!">Being for the Benefit of Mr. Kite!</a>" is an outstanding example."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMacDonald2005238_417-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMacDonald2005238-417">[407]</a></sup> Martin said of the two composers' distinct songwriting styles and his stabilising influence:
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>Compared with Paul's songs, all of which seemed to keep in some sort of touch with reality, John's had a psychedelic, almost mystical quality ... John's imagery is one of the best things about his work – 'tangerine trees', 'marmalade skies', 'cellophane flowers' ... I always saw him as an aural <a href="/wiki/Salvador_Dal%C3%AD" title="Salvador Dalí">Salvador Dalí</a>, rather than some drug-ridden record artist. On the other hand, I would be stupid to pretend that drugs didn't figure quite heavily in the Beatles' lives at that time ... they knew that I, in my schoolmasterly role, didn't approve ... Not only was I not into it myself, I couldn't see the need for it; and there's no doubt that, if I too had been on dope, <i>Pepper</i> would never have been the album it was. Perhaps it was the combination of dope and no dope that worked, who knows?<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMartin1979205–206_418-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMartin1979205–206-418">[408]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>Harrison echoed Martin's description of his stabilising role: "I think we just grew through those years together, him as the straight man and us as the loonies; but he was always there for us to interpret our madness – we used to be slightly avant-garde on certain days of the week, and he would be there as the anchor person, to communicate that through the engineers and on to the tape."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarry2003264_419-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarry2003264-419">[409]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="In_the_studio">In the studio</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Recording_practices_of_the_Beatles" title="Recording practices of the Beatles">Recording practices of the Beatles</a></div>
<p>Making innovative use of technology while expanding the possibilities of recorded music, the Beatles urged experimentation by Martin and his recording engineers. Seeking ways to put chance occurrences to creative use, accidental guitar feedback, a resonating glass bottle, a tape loaded the wrong way round so that it played backwards – any of these might be incorporated into their music.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHertsgaard1995103_420-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHertsgaard1995103-420">[410]</a></sup> Their desire to create new sounds on every new recording, combined with Martin's arranging abilities and the studio expertise of EMI staff engineers Norman Smith, <a href="/wiki/Ken_Townsend" title="Ken Townsend">Ken Townsend</a> and Geoff Emerick, all contributed significantly to their records from <i>Rubber Soul</i> and, especially, <i>Revolver</i> onwards.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHertsgaard1995103_420-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHertsgaard1995103-420">[410]</a></sup>
</p><p>Along with innovative studio techniques such as <a href="/wiki/Audio_signal_processing" title="Audio signal processing">sound effects</a>, unconventional microphone placements, tape loops, <a href="/wiki/Double_tracking" title="Double tracking">double tracking</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vari-speed" title="Vari-speed">vari-speed</a> recording, the Beatles augmented their songs with instruments that were unconventional in rock music at the time. These included string and brass ensembles as well as Indian instruments such as the sitar in "Norwegian Wood" and the <a href="/wiki/Swarmandal" title="Swarmandal">swarmandal</a> in "Strawberry Fields Forever".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMacDonald2005212_421-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMacDonald2005212-421">[411]</a></sup> They also used novel electronic instruments such as the Mellotron, with which McCartney supplied the flute voices on the "Strawberry Fields Forever" intro,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMacDonald2005219_422-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMacDonald2005219-422">[412]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Clavioline" title="Clavioline">clavioline</a>, an electronic keyboard that created the unusual oboe-like sound on "<a href="/wiki/Baby,_You%27re_a_Rich_Man" title="Baby, You're a Rich Man">Baby, You're a Rich Man</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMacDonald2005259_423-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMacDonald2005259-423">[413]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legacy">Legacy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cultural_impact_of_the_Beatles" title="Cultural impact of the Beatles">Cultural impact of the Beatles</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:254px;max-width:254px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:252px;max-width:252px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Beatles_on_Green_Hill_in_Almaty,_Kazakhstan.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2459" data-file-width="3819" decoding="async" height="161" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/The_Beatles_on_Green_Hill_in_Almaty%2C_Kazakhstan.jpg/250px-The_Beatles_on_Green_Hill_in_Almaty%2C_Kazakhstan.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/The_Beatles_on_Green_Hill_in_Almaty%2C_Kazakhstan.jpg/375px-The_Beatles_on_Green_Hill_in_Almaty%2C_Kazakhstan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/The_Beatles_on_Green_Hill_in_Almaty%2C_Kazakhstan.jpg/500px-The_Beatles_on_Green_Hill_in_Almaty%2C_Kazakhstan.jpg 2x" width="250"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><i><a href="/wiki/The_Beatles_Monument_(Almaty)" title="The Beatles Monument (Almaty)">The Beatles Monument</a></i> in <a href="/wiki/Almaty" title="Almaty">Almaty</a>, Kazakhstan</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:252px;max-width:252px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Beatles_Statues.jpg"><img alt="Statue in Liverpool" data-file-height="2448" data-file-width="3264" decoding="async" height="188" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/The_Beatles_Statues.jpg/250px-The_Beatles_Statues.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/The_Beatles_Statues.jpg/375px-The_Beatles_Statues.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/The_Beatles_Statues.jpg/500px-The_Beatles_Statues.jpg 2x" width="250"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The Beatles statue at <a href="/wiki/Pier_Head" title="Pier Head">Pier Head</a> in their home city Liverpool</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:252px;max-width:252px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Alistar_and_Alfio_from_The_Cairos_cross_Abbey_Road_with_Jesse_Davidson_and_Dj_Sammy_T.jpg"><img alt="Road crossing in London" data-file-height="720" data-file-width="960" decoding="async" height="188" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Alistar_and_Alfio_from_The_Cairos_cross_Abbey_Road_with_Jesse_Davidson_and_Dj_Sammy_T.jpg/250px-Alistar_and_Alfio_from_The_Cairos_cross_Abbey_Road_with_Jesse_Davidson_and_Dj_Sammy_T.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Alistar_and_Alfio_from_The_Cairos_cross_Abbey_Road_with_Jesse_Davidson_and_Dj_Sammy_T.jpg/375px-Alistar_and_Alfio_from_The_Cairos_cross_Abbey_Road_with_Jesse_Davidson_and_Dj_Sammy_T.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Alistar_and_Alfio_from_The_Cairos_cross_Abbey_Road_with_Jesse_Davidson_and_Dj_Sammy_T.jpg/500px-Alistar_and_Alfio_from_The_Cairos_cross_Abbey_Road_with_Jesse_Davidson_and_Dj_Sammy_T.jpg 2x" width="250"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href='/wiki/Abbey_Road#Abbey_Road_crossing_and_"Paul_is_dead"' title="Abbey Road">Abbey Road crossing</a> in London is a popular destination for Beatles fans. In December 2010 it was given <a href="/wiki/Listed_building#Grade_II" title="Listed building">grade II listed</a> status for its "cultural and historical importance"; the Abbey Road studios themselves had been given similar status earlier in the year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424"><a href="#cite_note-424">[414]</a></sup></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Former <i>Rolling Stone</i> associate editor <a href="/wiki/Robert_Greenfield" title="Robert Greenfield">Robert Greenfield</a> compared the Beatles to <a href="/wiki/Pablo_Picasso" title="Pablo Picasso">Picasso</a>, as "artists who broke through the constraints of their time period to come up with something that was unique and original ... [I]n the form of popular music, no one will ever be more revolutionary, more creative and more distinctive ..."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNN_Gross_361-1"><a href="#cite_note-CNN_Gross-361">[351]</a></sup> The British poet <a href="/wiki/Philip_Larkin" title="Philip Larkin">Philip Larkin</a> described their work as "an enchanting and intoxicating hybrid of Negro rock-and-roll with their own adolescent romanticism", and "the first advance in popular music since the War".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425"><a href="#cite_note-425">[415]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Beatles' 1964 arrival in the US is credited with initiating the <a href="/wiki/Album_era" title="Album era">album era</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[416]</a></sup> the music historian <a href="/wiki/Joel_Whitburn" title="Joel Whitburn">Joel Whitburn</a> says that LP sales soon "exploded and eventually outpaced the sales and releases of singles" in the music industry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427"><a href="#cite_note-427">[417]</a></sup> They not only sparked the British Invasion of the US,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEverett1999277_428-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEverett1999277-428">[418]</a></sup> they became a globally influential phenomenon as well.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould20078_429-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould20078-429">[419]</a></sup> From the 1920s, the US had dominated popular entertainment culture throughout much of the world, via <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_the_United_States" title="Cinema of the United States">Hollywood</a> films, <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">jazz</a>, the music of Broadway and <a href="/wiki/Tin_Pan_Alley" title="Tin Pan Alley">Tin Pan Alley</a> and, later, the rock and roll that first emerged in <a href="/wiki/Memphis,_Tennessee" title="Memphis, Tennessee">Memphis, Tennessee</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould20079_347-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould20079-347">[337]</a></sup> The Beatles are regarded as British cultural icons, with young adults from abroad naming the band among a group of people whom they most associated with UK culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[420]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[421]</a></sup>
</p><p>Their musical innovations and commercial success inspired musicians worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould20078_429-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould20078-429">[419]</a></sup> Many artists have acknowledged the Beatles' influence and enjoyed chart success with <a href="/wiki/List_of_cover_versions_of_Beatles_songs" title="List of cover versions of Beatles songs">covers of their songs</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-432"><a href="#cite_note-432">[422]</a></sup> On radio, their arrival marked the beginning of a new era; in 1968 the programme director of New York's <a href="/wiki/WABC_(AM)" title="WABC (AM)">WABC</a> radio station forbade his DJs from playing any "pre-Beatles" music, marking the defining line of what would be considered <a href="/wiki/Oldies" title="Oldies">oldies</a> on American radio.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFisher2007198_433-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFisher2007198-433">[423]</a></sup> They helped to redefine the album as something more than just a few hits padded out with "<a href="/wiki/Filler_(media)" title="Filler (media)">filler</a>",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEverett199991_434-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEverett199991-434">[424]</a></sup> and they were primary innovators of the modern music video.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpitz2005609–610_435-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpitz2005609–610-435">[425]</a></sup> The Shea Stadium show with which they opened their <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles%27_1965_US_tour" title="The Beatles' 1965 US tour">1965 North American tour</a> attracted an estimated 55,600 people,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992181_150-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisohn1992181-150">[144]</a></sup> then the largest audience in concert history; Spitz describes the event as a "major breakthrough ... a giant step toward reshaping the concert business".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpitz2005576–578_436-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpitz2005576–578-436">[426]</a></sup> Emulation of their clothing and especially their hairstyles, which became a mark of rebellion, had a global impact on fashion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2007345_105-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2007345-105">[102]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Gould, the Beatles changed the way people listened to popular music and experienced its role in their lives. From what began as the Beatlemania fad, the group's popularity grew into what was seen as an embodiment of sociocultural movements of the decade. As icons of the <a href="/wiki/Counterculture_of_the_1960s" title="Counterculture of the 1960s">1960s counterculture</a>, Gould continues, they became a catalyst for <a href="/wiki/Bohemianism" title="Bohemianism">bohemianism</a> and activism in various social and political arenas, fuelling movements such as <a href="/wiki/Feminist_movement" title="Feminist movement">women's liberation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gay_liberation" title="Gay liberation">gay liberation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Environmental_movement" title="Environmental movement">environmentalism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould20078–9_437-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould20078–9-437">[427]</a></sup> According to Peter Lavezzoli, after the "more popular than Jesus" controversy in 1966, the Beatles felt considerable pressure to say the right things and "began a concerted effort to spread a message of wisdom and higher consciousness".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELavezzoli2006176_175-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELavezzoli2006176-175">[168]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other commentators such as Mikal Gilmore and Todd Leopold have traced the inception of their socio-cultural impact earlier, interpreting even the Beatlemania period, particularly on their first visit to the US, as a key moment in the development of generational awareness.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gimore_(RS_Beatles/Dylan/60s)_103-1"><a href="#cite_note-Gimore_(RS_Beatles/Dylan/60s)-103">[100]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Leopold_(Beatlemania/CNN)_438-0"><a href="#cite_note-Leopold_(Beatlemania/CNN)-438">[428]</a></sup> Referring to their appearance on <i>the Ed Sullivan Show</i> Leopold states: "In many ways, the Sullivan appearance marked the beginning of a cultural revolution ... The Beatles were like aliens dropped into the United States of 1964."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Leopold_(Beatlemania/CNN)_438-1"><a href="#cite_note-Leopold_(Beatlemania/CNN)-438">[428]</a></sup> According to Gilmore:
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>Elvis Presley had shown us how rebellion could be fashioned into eye-opening style; the Beatles were showing us how style could have the impact of cultural revelation – or at least how a pop vision might be forged into an unimpeachable consensus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gimore_(RS_Beatles/Dylan/60s)_103-2"><a href="#cite_note-Gimore_(RS_Beatles/Dylan/60s)-103">[100]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>Established in 2009, <a href="/wiki/Global_Beatles_Day" title="Global Beatles Day">Global Beatles Day</a> is an annual holiday on 25 June each year that honours and celebrates the ideals of the Beatles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439"><a href="#cite_note-439">[429]</a></sup> The date was chosen to commemorate the date the group participated in the <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a> programme <i><a href="/wiki/Our_World_(1967_TV_program)" title="Our World (1967 TV program)">Our World</a></i> in 1967, performing "<a href="/wiki/All_You_Need_Is_Love" title="All You Need Is Love">All You Need Is Love</a>" broadcast to an international audience.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440"><a href="#cite_note-440">[430]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards_and_achievements">Awards and achievements</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_awards_and_nominations_received_by_the_Beatles" title="List of awards and nominations received by the Beatles">List of awards and nominations received by the Beatles</a></div>
<p>In 1965, Queen Elizabeth II appointed Lennon, McCartney, Harrison and Starr Members of the <a href="/wiki/Order_of_the_British_Empire" title="Order of the British Empire">Order of the British Empire</a> (MBE).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpitz2005556_139-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpitz2005556-139">[133]</a></sup> The Beatles won the 1971 Academy Award for <a
